{{Use Australian English|date=July 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2017}} {{Infobox Officeholder |name = Dick Kimber |image = |imagesize = |smallimage = <!--If this is specified, "image" should not be.--> |alt = |caption = |birth_date = 1939 |birth_place = [[Freeling, South Australia|Freeling]] in [[South Australia]] |death_date = |death_place = |birthname = Richard Glyn Kimber |nationality = Australian |spouse = Margaret Friedel |children = Steve, Barbara |occupation = Historian |website = }} '''Richard “Dick” Glyn Kimber AM''' (born 1939) is an Australian historian and author who has written extensively on the history, art, culture and wildlife of Central Australia. He has published several books, the best known of which is ''Man From Arltunga: Walter Smith, Australian Bushman'' as well as more than 100 articles and essays.
==Early life==
Kimber was born at [[Freeling, South Australia|Freeling]] in [[South Australia]] in 1939. He went to school in the Riverland area and Brighton and then attended [[Adelaide University]] and Adelaide Teacher’s College.<ref name="CDU" />
==Career==
Throughout Kimber’s adult life, his focus has been on historical research, Aboriginal art and culture, and wildlife. He has published several books, the best known of which is ''Man From Arltunga: Walter Smith, Australian Bushman''. He has also published over 100 articles and essays. He has also given public lectures<ref>{{cite web|last1=Foyster|first1=Scott|title=Everyday anthropology|url=https://overland.org.au/2010/09/everyday-anthropology/|website=Overland: Progressive culture since 1954|accessdate=29 May 2017|date=19 September 2010}}</ref> and made regular media appearances.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Maloney|first1=Nadine|title=Local historian Dick Kimber on John McDouall Stuart|url=https://soundcloud.com/abc-alice-springs/local-historian-dick-kimber-on-john-mcdouall-stuart|accessdate=19 June 2017|agency=ABC Alice Springs|publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation|date=2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=First Australians – Episode 4, No Other Law|url=https://aso.gov.au/titles/documentaries/first-australians-episode-4/clip3/|website=Australian Screen|publisher=National Film and Sound Archive|accessdate=19 June 2017}}</ref>
Kimber moved to [[Alice Springs]] in 1970 and taught English, history, social science and Aboriginal Studies at Alice Springs High School. In 1974 he became the first Sacred Sites Officer in the Northern Territory for the Sacred Sites Authority, before returning to teaching. From 1976 to 1978 he was the Papunya Tula Artists Coordinator and devised Aboriginal Studies materials for schools, after which he again returned to teaching. Beginning in 1976 Kimber undertook research and prepared submissions for land rights and [[Native title in Australia|native title claims]] for over twenty years, in a private capacity and for the [[Central Land Council]] and Ngaanyatjarra Council. During this time he also undertook research for the Australian Institute of Aboriginal And Torres Strait Islander Studies, the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, the Australian Heritage Commission and the [[Strehlow Research Centre]], regarding locations of Aboriginal homelands and their needs, settlement history, and ownership of sacred objects. He researched the historical records of extinct and rare native fauna for the Conservation Commission of the Northern Territory and provided advice regarding the development of the Alice Springs Desert Park and issues relating to Aboriginal land ownership of various parks and reserves.<ref name="Alice news">{{cite news|last1=Finnane|first1=Finnane|title=Dick Kimber: premier scholar of Central Australia|url=http://www.alicespringsnews.com.au/2017/05/12/dick-kimber-premier-scholar-of-central-australia/|accessdate=29 May 2017|agency=Alice Springs News online|date=12 May 2017}}</ref>
From the mid-1990s, Kimber advised the [[National Museum of Australia]],<ref>{{cite web|title=‘Story of the Women’s Camp’|url=http://www.nma.gov.au/collections/highlights/story_of_the_womens_camp|website=National Museum of Australia|publisher=National Museum of Australia|accessdate=19 June 2017}}</ref> [[Museum Victoria]] and the [[Museum and Art Gallery of the Northern Territory|Northern Territory Museum]] regarding Aboriginal artefacts and cultural practices,<ref name="Musvic" /> access to Papunya Tula paintings that incorporated sacred elements, and the return of sacred objects to traditional custodians in central Australia. He continues to consult for Museum Victoria is association with the Strehlow Research Centre.
Since arriving in central Australia Kimber has undertaken travels, discussions and other shared experiences with many Aboriginal people, primarily in the south-western Simpson Desert, western deserts of central Australia and the deserts of Western Australia through to the Canning Stock-Route, and in Alice Springs. He has privately researched significant historical figures in inland Australia, Australian language usage, and native fauna of the inland including birds, and made important contributions to the Australian Language Dictionary, the Australian Dictionary of Biography<ref>{{cite web|last1=Kimber|first1=R. G.|title=Smith, Walter (1898–1990)|url=http://adb.anu.edu.au/biography/smith-walter-15740|website=Australian Dictionary of Biography|publisher=National Centre of Biography, Australian National University|accessdate=19 June 2017|date=2012}}</ref> and the Northern Territory Dictionary of Biography.<ref>{{cite web|title=Northern Territory Dictionary of Biography|url=http://hdl.handle.net/10070/260154|website=Territory Stories|publisher=Northern Territory Library|accessdate=19 June 2017|date=2008}}</ref> The National Library of Australia has established the RG Kimber Collection for his correspondence and records.
Kimber was awarded an Australia Media in 2001 for "services to the community through research projects and the recording of information of national interest in the areas of history, anthropology, Aboriginal art, ecology and land management practices in Central Australia".<ref name="Gazette">{{cite web|title=The Queen's Birthday 2001 Honours|url=https://www.gg.gov.au/sites/default/files/files/honours/QB01.pdf|website=Governor-General of the Commonwealth of Australia|publisher=Commonwealth of Australia Gazette|accessdate=18 June 2017|date=11 June 2001}}</ref> Kimber was awarded a Doctor of Letters, Honoris Causa from the [[Charles Darwin University]] in 2006.<ref>{{cite web|title=Prominent Central Australians to be honoured at CDU Alice Springs graduation|url=http://ext.cdu.edu.au/newsroom/a/2006/Pages/1068.aspx.html|website=Charles Darwin University|accessdate=29 May 2017|date=16 June 2006}}</ref><ref name="CDU">{{cite web|title=Richard Glyn Kimber|url=https://www.cdu.edu.au/sites/default/files/governance/docs/Richard-Glyn-Kimber.pdf|website=Charles Darwin University|accessdate=29 May 2017}}</ref>
==Personal life== Kimber married to scientist Margret Friedel in 1980. He has two children Steve and Barbara. In 1980, Kimber resigned from the Education Department “becoming Alice Springs’ first publicly acknowledged ‘house-husband’" while continuing his active writing life.<ref name="Alice news" />
He is passionate about [[Australian rules football|Australia Rules Football]], [[lifesaving]] as well as history. He was the foundation captain and coach of the Melanka AFL Football Club (now West Football Club).<ref>{{cite web|title=History of the West Football Club|url=http://westfootballclub.com.au/the-club/history|website=The Bloods: West Football Club|accessdate=29 May 2017}}</ref>

{{For|the writer|Ding Ling}} {{For|the tomb|Dingling (Ming)}} {{Refimprove|date=May 2010}} The '''Dingling''' ({{zh|c=丁零}}) were an ancient people mentioned in [[Chinese historiography]] in the context of the 1st century BCE. They are assumed to have been an early Proto-[[Turkic peoples|Turkic-speaking people]],<ref> Hyun Jin Kim: [https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&id=fX8YAAAAQBAJ&q=Dingling+Turkic#v=snippet&q=Dingling%20Turkic&f=false The Huns, Rome and the Birth of Europe]. Cambridge University Press, 2013. pp.175-176. Victor H. Mair: [https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&id=8-OilJCX1moC&q=Tingling+Turkic#v=snippet&q=Tingling%20Turkic&f=false Contact And Exchange in the Ancient World]. University of Hawaii Press, 2006. p.140</ref> whose original constituents mainly assimilated into the [[Xiongnu]] and [[Xianbei]] groups.{{Citation needed|date=March 2011}} They originally lived on the bank of the [[Lena River]] in the area west of [[Lake Baikal]], gradually moving southward to [[Mongolia]] and northern China. They were a huge independent horde for centuries, but later been defeated and temporary became subject of the [[Xiongnu]] Empire,<ref>Lu (1996), pp. 111, 135-137.</ref><ref>Li (2003), pp. 110-112.</ref> and thus presumably related to the invaders known as [[Huns]] in the west.<ref>A. J. Haywood, [https://books.google.com/books?id=YKPaLi1d1O4C Siberia: A Cultural History], Oxford University Press, 2010, p.203</ref> Around the 3rd century they were assimilated into the [[Tiele people|Tiele]],<ref>Victor H. Mair: [https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&id=8-OilJCX1moC&q=Tingling+Turkic#v=snippet&q=Tingling%20Turkic&f=false Contact And Exchange in the Ancient World]. University of Hawaii Press, 2006. p.140</ref> also named Di (翟)， DiLi (狄历)， Gaoche (高車) or Chile (敕勒), who gradually expanded westward into [[Central Asia]], expelled from [[Mongolia]] by the [[Rouran]] and establishing a state [[Turpan]] in the 5th century. The Tiele were a collection of [[Turkic peoples|early Turkic]] tribes, largely descended from the Chile.
== Origin and migration == The Dingling were a warlike group of hunters, fishers, and gatherers of the southern Siberian mountain taiga region from Lake Baikal to northern [[Mongolia]]. Chinese records do not mention the physical appearance of the Dingling, suggesting general homogeneity with people of the Asiatic region, and their name appears rarely, such as Di (翟), a example of the family name that been translated based on their group name or the last name of the top Ruling class.<ref>Xue (1992), pp. 54-60.</ref><ref>Lu (1996), pp. 305-320.</ref><ref>Duan (1988) pp. 35-53.</ref>
They might have been correlated with the [[Guifang]], a northern tribe that appears in the [[oracle bone]] inscriptions from [[Yinxu]].<ref>Duan (1988) pp. 8-11.</ref>
According to the ''History of the Gaoche'' of [[Wei Shou]] (6th century), the origin of the Dingling can be traced to the Chidi or Red Di (赤狄), who lived in northern China during the [[Spring and Autumn period]]. The ''[[Mozi]]'' mentions a total of eight Di groups related to the Chidi, of whom only the Chidi and two others were known.<ref>Duan (1988), pp. 1-6</ref><ref>Suribadalaha (1986), p. 27.</ref>
To the north of the [[Xiongnu]] empire and Dingling territories, at the headwaters of the [[Yenisei]] around [[Tannu Uriankhai]], lived the ''Gekun'' (鬲昆), also known as the [[Yenisei Kirghiz]] in later records. Further to the west near the [[Irtysh]] river lived the Hujie (呼揭). Other tribes living north of the Xiongnu, such as the Hunyu (浑庾), Qushe (屈射), and Xinli (薪犁), are only mentioned once in Chinese records, and their exact location is unknown.<ref>Lu (1996), p. 136.</ref><ref>Shen (1998), p. 75.</ref>
During the 2nd century BCE, the Dingling became subjects of [[Modu Chanyu]] along with 26 other tribes, including the [[Yuezhi]] and [[Wusun]].<ref>Li (2003), p. 73.</ref>
===Dingling and Xiongnu===
The Dingling were first subjugated by the [[Xiongnu]], but these gradually weakened. In 71 BCE, after numerous conflicts between the Chinese and the Xiongnu, the Dingling, with help from neighboring tribes, took the opportunity to revolt. From 63 to 60 BCE, during a split within the Xiongnu ruling clan of Luanti (挛鞮), the Dingling attacked the Xiongnu, together with the [[Wusun]], supported by the Chinese, from the west and the [[Wuhuan]] from the southeast.<ref>Duan (1988) pp. 99-100.</ref>
In 51 BCE, they were, together with the Hujie and Gekun, defeated by the Xiongnu under [[Zhizhi Chanyu]], on his way to [[Kangju]]. Over the next century there may have been more uprisings, but the only recorded one was in the year 85, when together with the [[Xianbei]] they made their final attack on the Xiongnu.<ref>Duan (1988) pp. 101-103.</ref> After that, the Dingling were assimilated into the remaining northern Xiongnu and the [[Tuoba]] under the confederacy of Xianbei chief [[Tanshihuai]] (檀石槐). After his death in 181, the Xianbei moved south and the Dingling took their place on the steppe.
=== Assimilation===
Between the short-lived [[Xianbei]] confederacy in 181 and the foundation of the [[Rouran]] Qaghanate in 402, there was a long period without a tribal confederacy on the steppe. During this period, a part of the Dingling were assimilated to the northern Xiongnu by permanently settling further to the south.<ref>Duan (1988) pp. 111-113.</ref> Another group, documented as about 450,000, moved southeast and merged into the Xianbei.
After the defeat of [[Northern Shanyu (1st century)]], deduced from the number of casualties and immigrants, an estimated figure of 200,000 is given for the Xiongnu still remaining on the northern steppe. Remnants of the Xiongnu managed to keep their identity until the early 5th century, living on the [[Orkhon River]] under the tribal name ''Bayeqi'' (拔也稽) before being eliminated by the [[Rouran]].<ref>Duan (1988), pp. 118-120.</ref>
Some groups of Dingling settled in China during [[Wang Mang]]'s reign. According to the ''[[Weilüe]]'', another group of Dingling escaped to the western steppe in Kazakhstan, which beeb called the West Dingling.<ref>[http://depts.washington.edu/silkroad/texts/weilue/weilue.html#section28 Hill (2004), Section 28]</ref> Around the 3rd century, Dinglings living in China began to adopt family names such as Zhai(翟)or Di, Xianyu (鲜于), Luo (洛) and Yan (严).<ref>Duan (1988), pp. 137-142, 152-158.</ref> These Dingling became part of the southern Xiongnu tribes known as '''[[Tiele people|Chile]]''' (赤勒) during the 3rd century, from which the name Chile (敕勒) originated.
During the [[Sixteen Kingdoms]] period the West Dingling Khan Zhai Bin(翟斌) lead his hordes, migrate from Kazakhstan into Central China, serveing the Chinese Dynasty Qian Qin(前秦)， after series of betrayed and Chinese plotting against him, Zhai Bin revolted against the QianQin Dynasty. MuRongChui 慕容垂， a XianBei noble who was appointed the high command of QianQin army to take down the revolt, but ZhaiBin successfully persuade him to start mutiny against QianQin, then later with the support of other XianBei nobles, ZhaiBin supported MuRongChui to be the leader of the Anti-Qin leagues. End of the same year, MuRongChui self appointed King of Yan Dynasty(燕王), left ZhaiBin in a dilemma of war, murder ZhaiBin and his three sons. His nephew Zhaizhen(翟真) inherited the hordes, seeking for revenge, but later assassinated by his military advisor XianYuQi (鲜于乞), the DingLing soldiers executed XianYuQi, then elected ZhaiZhen's cousin ZhaiCheng(翟成) as the new Leader, but later also been murdered by XianBei, then ZhaiLiao 翟辽, became the new leader of the hordes, with the support, he founded the [[Wei (Dingling)|Wei state]], a DingLing Dynasty in China in modern HeNan Province.<ref>Duan (1988), pp. 148-152.</ref> A branch of people descended from the Tiele in central Asia, mixing with [[Proto-Indo-Europeans|Indo-European]] people, would later emerge as the [[Uyghur people|Uyghur]] group.
About one-quarter of the Tuoba clans show similar names as found among the later Gaoche and Tiele tribes. Among them, the Hegu (紇骨) and Yizhan (乙旃) clans kept their high status and were forbidden to intermarry with the rest.
Between the 4th and 7th centuries, the name "Dingling" slowly disappeared from Chinese records.
==Yeniseian theory== In ''Zur jenissejisch-indianischen Urverwandtschaft (Concerning Yeniseian-Indian Primal Relationship)'', the German scholar, Heinrich Werner developed a new language family which he termed ''Baikal–Siberic''. By extension, he groups together the [[Yeniseian languages|Yeniseian]] peoples ([[Arin language|Arin]], [[Assan language|Assan]], [[Yugh language|Yugh]], [[Ket language|Ket]], [[Kott language|Kott]], and [[Pumpokol language|Pumpokol]]), the [[Na-Dene]] Indians, and the Dingling of Chinese chronicles to ''Proto-Dingling''. The linguistic comparison of Na-Dene and Yeniseian shows that the quantity and character of the correspondences points to a possible common origin. According to Russian linguistic experts, they likely spoke a [[polysynthetic language|polysynthetic]] or [[synthetic language]] with an [[active language|active]] form of [[morphosyntactic alignment]], exhibiting a linguistically and culturally unified community.{{Citation needed|date=March 2011}}
The name Dingling can be seen to resemble both: * the Yeniseian word *dzheng ''people'' > Ket de?ng, Yug dyeng, Kott cheang * the Na-Dene word *ling or *hling ''people'', i.e. as manifested in the name of the [[Tlingit people|Tlingit]] (properly hling-git ''son of man, child of the people'').
Although the [[Dené–Yeniseian languages|Dené–Yeniseian]] language family is now a widely known proposal, his inclusion of the Dingling is not widely accepted.

page.title: Economic effects of the September 11 attacks

revision.text:
The '''economic effects of the September 11 attacks''' were initial shocks causing global [[stock markets]] to drop sharply.
The [[September 11 attacks]] themselves resulted in approximately $40 billion in [[insurance]] losses, making it one of the largest insured events ever.<ref name="crs-4"/>
==Financial markets== [[File:DJIA during 911.svg|thumb|300px|left|Stock exchanges closed between September 10, 2001 and September 17, 2001. After the initial panic, the [[Dow Jones Industrial Average|DJIA]] quickly rose for only a slight drop.]]
On Tuesday, September 11th, 2001, the opening of the [[New York Stock Exchange]] (NYSE) was delayed after [[American Airlines Flight 11|the first plane]] crashed into the [[World Trade Center (1973–2001)|World Trade Center]]'s North Tower, and trading for the day was canceled after [[United Airlines Flight 175|the second plane]] crashed into the South Tower. [[NASDAQ]] also canceled trading. The New York Stock Exchange was then evacuated as well as nearly all banks and financial institutions on [[Wall Street]] and in many cities across the country. The [[London Stock Exchange]] and other stock exchanges around the world were also closed down and evacuated in fear of follow-up terrorist attacks. The New York Stock Exchange remained closed until the following Monday. This was the third time in history that the NYSE experienced prolonged closure, the first time being in the early months of [[World War I]]<ref>forbes.com [https://www.forbes.com/sites/abrambrown/2012/10/29/what-can-close-the-nyse-world-war-presidential-funerals-and-hurricane-sandy/ What can close the NYSE?] 2012/10/29</ref><ref>[https://www.globalfinancialdata.com/gfdblog/?p=2750 Global financial data]</ref> and the second being March 1933 during the [[Great Depression]]. Trading on the United States [[bond market]] also ceased; the leading government bond trader, [[Cantor Fitzgerald]], was based in the World Trade Center.<ref name="norris">{{cite news |title=Stock|publisher=The New York Times |date=September 12, 2001 |author=Norris, Floyd, Jonathan Fuerbringer}}</ref> The [[New York Mercantile Exchange]] was also closed for a week after the attacks.<ref name="crs-2"/>
The [[Federal Reserve]] issued a statement, saying it was "open and operating. The [[discount window]] is available to meet [[liquidity]] needs.".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.federalreserve.gov/Boarddocs/press/general/2001/20010911/default.htm |title=Federal Reserve Release |publisher=Federal Reserve |date=September 11, 2001}}</ref> The Federal Reserve added $100 billion in liquidity per day, during the three days following the attack, to help avert a financial crisis.<ref name="crs-2">{{cite web |url=https://fas.org/irp/crs/RL31617.pdf |title=The Economic Effects of 9/11: A Retrospective Assessment |author=Makinen, Gail |date=September 27, 2002 |publisher=Congressional Research Service |pages=CRS–2}}</ref> Federal Reserve Governor [[Roger W. Ferguson Jr.]] has described in detail this and the other actions that the Fed undertook to maintain a stable economy and offset potential disruptions arising in the financial system.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.federalreserve.gov/boarddocs/speeches/2003/20030205/default.htm |title=September 11, the Federal Reserve, and the Financial System}}</ref>
[[Gold as an investment|Gold]] prices spiked upwards, from $215.50 to $287 an ounce in London trading.<ref name="norris"/> [[Price of oil|Oil prices]] also spiked upwards.<ref>{{cite news |title=The Financial World Is Left Reeling by Attack |publisher=The New York Times |date=September 12, 2001 |author=Stevenson, Richard W., Stephen Labaton}}</ref> Gas prices in the United States also briefly shot up, though the spike in prices lasted only about one week.<ref name="crs-2"/>
[[Currency]] trading continued, with the [[United States dollar]] falling sharply against the [[Euro]], [[Pound sterling|British pound]], and [[Japanese yen]].<ref name="norris"/> The next day, European stock markets fell sharply, including declines of 4.6% in [[Spain]], 8.5% in [[Germany]],<ref name="norris"/> and 5.7% on the London Stock Exchange.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/ft/20080121/bs_ft/fto012120081205391251 |title=Shares suffer biggest fall since September 11, 2001}}{{dead link|date=August 2014}}</ref> Stocks in the [[Latin America]]n markets also plunged, with a 9.2% drop in [[Brazil]], 5.2% drop in [[Argentina]], and 5.6% decline in Mexico, before trading was halted.<ref name="norris"/>
==Economic sectors== In international and domestic markets, stocks of companies in some sectors were hit particularly hard. Travel and entertainment stocks fell, while communications, pharmaceutical and military/defense stocks rose. Online travel agencies particularly suffered, as they cater to leisure travel.
===Insurance=== Insurance losses due to 9/11 were more than one and a half times greater than what was previously the largest disaster ([[Hurricane Andrew]]) in terms of losses. The losses included business interruption ($11.0 billion), property ($9.6 billion), [[liability (accounting)|liability]] ($7.5 billion), [[workers compensation]] ($1.8 billion), and others ($2.5 billion). The firms with the largest losses included [[Berkshire Hathaway]], [[Lloyd's]], [[Swiss Re]], and [[Munich Re]], all of which are reinsurers, with more than $2 billion in losses for each.<ref>{{cite journal |title=The Economic Effects Of Federal Participation In Terrorism Risk |journal=Risk Management & Insurance Review |year=2005 |author1=Hubbard, R Glenn |author2=Bruce Deal |author3=Peter Hess |doi=10.1111/j.1540-6296.2005.00056.x |volume=8 |issue=2 |pages=177}}</ref> Shares of major [[reinsurer]]s, including [[Swiss Re]] and [[Baloise Insurance Group]] dropped by more than 10%, while shares of [[Swiss Life]] dropped 7.8%.<ref>{{cite news |title=Reinsurance Companies Wait to Sort Out Cost of Damages |publisher=The New York Times |date=September 12, 2001 |author=Sorkin, Trimi Slade, Simon Romero}}</ref> Although the insurance industry held reserves that covered the 9/11 attacks, insurance companies were reluctant to continue providing coverage for future terrorist attacks. Only a few insurers continue to offer such coverage.
===Airlines and aviation=== Flights were grounded in various places across the United States and [[Canada]] that did not necessarily have the operational support in place, such as dedicated ground crews. A large number of transatlantic flights landed in [[Gander International Airport|Gander]] in [[Newfoundland and Labrador|Newfoundland]] and in [[Halifax Regional Municipality|Halifax]], [[Nova Scotia]], with the logistics handled by [[Transport Canada]] in [[Operation Yellow Ribbon]]. To help with immediate needs for victims' families, [[United Airlines]] and [[American Airlines]] both provided initial payments of $25,000.<ref name="zuckerman">{{cite news |title=For the First Time, the Nation's Entire Airspace Is Shut Down |publisher=The New York Times |date=September 12, 2001 |author=Zuckerman, Laurence}}</ref> The airlines were also required to refund ticket purchases for anyone unable to fly.<ref name="zuckerman"/>
The 9/11 attacks compounded financial troubles that the airline industry already was experiencing before the attacks. Share prices of airlines and airplane manufacturers plummeted after the attacks. [[Midway Airlines (1993–2003)|Midway Airlines]], already on the brink of bankruptcy, shut down operations almost immediately afterwards. Other airlines were threatened with bankruptcy, and tens of thousands of layoffs were announced in the week following the attacks. To help the industry, the federal government provided an aid package to the industry, including $10 billion in [[loan guarantee]]s, along with $5 billion for short-term assistance.<ref name="crs-4">{{cite web |url=https://fas.org/irp/crs/RL31617.pdf |title=The Economic Effects of 9/11: A Retrospective Assessment |author=Makinen, Gail |date=September 27, 2002 |publisher=Congressional Research Service |pages=CRS–4}}</ref>
The reduction on air travel demand caused by the attack is also seen as a contributory reason to the retirement of the only supersonic aircraft in service at the time, [[Concorde]].<ref>[https://www.independent.co.uk/travel/news-and-advice/concorde-and-supersonic-travel-the-days-when-the-sun-rose-in-the-west-8888836.html Concorde and supersonic travel: The days when the sun rose in the west]</ref> It has also been commented that the lack of demand for the Concorde after its service resumption in 2001 could be caused by the death of many regular Concorde travellers resulted from this attack.<ref>[https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-108568698.html 9/11 'grounded Concorde'.]</ref>
===Tourism=== Tourism in [[New York City]] plummeted, causing massive losses in a sector which employed 280,000 people and generated $25 billion per year. In the week following the attack, hotel occupancy fell below 40%, and 3,000 employees were laid off. [[Tourism]], hotel occupancy and air travel also fell drastically across the nation.{{Citation needed|date=September 2009}} The reluctance to fly may have been due to increased fear of a repeat attack. Suzanne Thompson, Professor of Psychology at Pomona College, [[California]] conducted [https://web.archive.org/web/20130927161530/http://collegenews.org/news/2003/study-on-effects-of-911-attacks-show-most-americans-feel-more-vulnerable.html interviews of 501 people who were not direct victims of 9/11]. From this, she concluded that "Most participants felt more distress (65 percent) and a stronger fear of flying (55 percent) immediately after the event than they did before the attacks."
===Security=== Since the 9/11 attacks, substantial resources have been put towards improving security, in the areas of [[homeland security]], [[defense (military)|national defense]], and in the private sector.<ref name="crs-2"/>
==New York City== In New York City, approximately 430,000 jobs were lost and there were $2.8 billion in lost wages over the three months following the 9/11 attacks. The economic effects were mainly focused on the city's [[export]] economy sectors.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Dolfman, Michael L., Solidelle F. Wasser |journal=Monthly Labor Review |volume=127 |year=2004 |title=9/11 and the New York City Economy}}</ref> The [[GDP]] for New York City was estimated to have declined by $30.3 billion over the last three months of 2001 and all of 2002. The Federal government provided $11.2 billion in immediate assistance to the [[Government of New York City]] in September 2001, and $10.5 billion in early 2002 for economic development and infrastructure needs.<ref name="crs-5"/>
The 9/11 attacks also had great impact on small businesses in [[Lower Manhattan]], located near the [[World Trade Center (1973–2001)|World Trade Center]]. Approximately 18,000 [[small business]]es were destroyed or displaced after the attacks. The [[Small Business Administration]] provided loans as assistance, while Community Development Block Grants and Economic Injury Disaster Loans were other also used by the Federal Government to provide assistance to small business affected by the 9/11 attacks.<ref name="crs-5">{{cite web |url=https://fas.org/irp/crs/RL31617.pdf |title=The Economic Effects of 9/11: A Retrospective Assessment |author=Makinen, Gail |date=September 27, 2002 |publisher=Congressional Research Service |pages=CRS–5}}</ref>
==Other effects== The September 11 attacks also led directly to the U.S. war in Afghanistan, as well as additional homeland security spending. The attacks were also cited as a [[rationale for the Iraq war]]. The cost of the two wars so far has surpassed $5 trillion.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/economy/osama-bin-laden-didnt-win-but-he-was-enormously-successful/2011/05/02/AFexZjbF_story.html | work=The Washington Post | first=Suzy | last=Khimm | date=May 3, 2011 | title=Osama bin Laden didn't win, but he was ‘enormously successful'}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/ezra-klein/post/bin-ladens-war-against-the-us-economy/2011/04/27/AFDOPjfF_blog.html | work=The Washington Post | date=May 3, 2011 | first=Thomas | last=Heath | title=Bin Laden's war against the U.S. economy}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [https://www.nytimes.com/2002/09/08/nyregion/08ECON.html Attack Gave a Devastating Shove to the City's Teetering Economy, ''The New York Times'', September 8, 2002] * [https://www.nytimes.com/2002/09/16/nyregion/16DOWN.html As Companies Scatter, Doubts on Return of Financial District], ''The New York Times'', September 16, 2002

'''Elizabeth Cooper''' ([[floruit|fl.]] 1865–1874) was an English historian and biographer of the mid-Victorian period, known for three publications on the history of America, on [[Lady Arbella Stuart]], and on [[Thomas Wentworth, 1st Earl of Strafford]].
==Biography== Little appears to be known of Cooper apart from her publications, and a few reviews and commentaries relating to them; she appears to have been unmarried, at least during the period in which she was published.<ref name="ODNB">{{cite ODNB|id=46555|title=Cooper, Elizabeth (fl. 1865–1874), historian|first=Rosemary|last=Mitchell}}</ref>
In 1865 she published ''A Popular History of America'', subtitled '' From the Discovery by Columbus to the Establishment of the Federal Republic of the United States In Three Periods: I. The Discovery and Conquest of the West Indies and South America II. The Colonization of the United States III. The War of Independence and the Establishment of the Federal Government''. The history, covering both the north and south of the continent, runs to 527 pages and includes two fold-out maps.<ref name="ODNB"/><ref name="AAB">{{cite web|url=http://www.all-antique-books.com/book-34423-A-Popular-History-of-America-Antique-Book-w-Maps-1865|title=A Popular History of America Antique Book w/ Maps 1865|website=All Antique Books|accessdate=6 November 2016}}</ref>
In the following year, 1866, she published a two-volume ''The Life and Letters of Lady Arabella Stuart'', based on her studies of Stuart-related papers held by [[Thomas Phillipps]], [[Richard Monckton Milnes, 1st Baron Houghton]], [[George Digby Wingfield Digby]] and others.<ref name="ODNB"/><ref name="Stuart1">{{cite book|title=The Life and Letters of Lady Arbella Stuart |first=Elizabeth |last=Cooper |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=jJIEAAAAYAAJ|date=1866|pages=vii-viii}}</ref> The ''Westminster and Foreign Quarterly Review'' described the work as a carefully painted portrait, built on 'numerous original and hitherto unpublished documents', and written with 'quiet taste and sober treatment'.<ref name="FQWR">{{cite journal|journal=Westminster and Foreign Quarterly Review|title=Contemporary Literature|volume=30|date=1 July 1866|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=HvFTAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA257|pages=257–8}}</ref>
She next published ''The Life of Thomas Wentworth, Earl of Stafford'' in 1874; the [[Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]] speculates that the gap between this and the ''Arabella Stuart'' might arise out of illness; her dedication in ''Stafford'' is to Edward Lane, a medical doctor and [[Hydrotherapy|hydrotherapist]] who ran establishments at [[Moor Park, Farnham]] and [[Sudbrook Park, Petersham]]; Cooper evidently believed he had rescued her from certain death.<ref name="Stafford1">{{cite book|title=The Life of Thomas Wentworth Earl of Strafford & Lord- Lieutenant ..., Volume 1|first=Elizabeth|last=Cooper|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=KL1gAAAAcAAJ|date=1874|page=Dedication}}</ref> The two-volume ''Stafford'' was the first scholarly treatise on Wentworth, and was received with generally good reviews.<ref name="ODNB"/>
==Works== [[File:Lady Arbella Stuart - miniature.png|thumb|150px|Engraving of Lady Arbella Stuart, commissioned by Cooper and based on a miniature in the possession of George Digby Wingfield Digby]] *''[https://books.google.ca/books?id=xrdXAAAAcAAJ A Popular History of America]'' (1865) *''The Life and Letters of Lady Arabella Stuart'' (1866) **[https://archive.org/details/lifeandlettersl00coopgoog volume 1] **[https://archive.org/details/lifeandlettersl02coopgoog volume 2] *''The Life of Thomas Wentworth, Earl of Stafford '' (1874) **[https://archive.org/details/lifethomaswentw00coopgoog volume 1] **[https://archive.org/details/lifethomaswentw02coopgoog volume 2]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
