91126 Schwabach |website = [https://www.schwabach.de/ www.schwabach.de] |mayor = Matthias Thürauf |Bürgermeistertitel= Oberbürgermeister |party = CSU }} '''Schwabach''' ({{IPA-de|ˈʃvaːbax}}) is a [[Germany|German]] [[Town#Germany|town]] of about 40,000 inhabitants near [[Nuremberg]] in the centre of the region of [[Franconia]] in the north of [[Bavaria]]. The city is an autonomous administrative district (''kreisfreie Stadt''). Schwabach is also the name of the river which runs through the city prior joining the [[Rednitz]]. Schwabach is famous for its crafts made of [[gold]], particularly [[metal leaf|gold foil]]. In 2004, Schwabach celebrated this tradition with an anniversary festival, marking "500 years gold foil in Schwabach". Around 1500, a local typesetter developed the "[[Schwabacher]]" font. This font was used for printing the first Bible in German, which had been worked out by [[Martin Luther]]. Schwabach is also the birthplace of composer [[Adolf von Henselt]], the botanist [[Johann Gottfried Zinn]], the biologist [[Ralf Baumeister]] and one of the developers of [[MP3]], [[Bernhard Grill]]. It was often visited by [[Albrecht Dürer]]. ==Etymology== The name derives from the old [[Franconia]]n name ''Suapaha'' (later ''Suabaha'', then ''Villa Suabach'') which translates as "Schwaben-Bach" in modern [[German language|German]], which means "[[Swabia]]n [[stream]]", the first part of the name was given by the Franconians who came to the area about a millennium after the [[Hallstatt culture]] to the people living on the banks of that stream, which were perceived as "[[Swabia]]ns" by them, while the second part of the name is a reference to the stream which flows through town. ==Timeline== [[Image:Golddach fcm.jpg|thumb|left|The gold roof of the Schwabach town hall]] *750 BC–AD 500: Archaeological evidence of settlement. *600–700: Name Schwabach first used to refer to the settlement and the river. *1346: City wall built. *1371: Municipal law established. *1469: Town church built (still in use). *1500: (ca.) Schwabacher font invented. *1528: City hall built (still in use). *1633: First needle factory established in Schwabach. *1723: Schwabach river flooded to highest point ever. Markings of the flood are still visible. *1768: The landmark ''Old [[Tilia|Linden Tree]]'' planted (still there). *1792: Schwabach became part of [[Prussia]]. *1797: [[Goethe]] stayed overnight in Schwabach. *1806: Schwabach became part of Bavaria. *1849: Railway station built. *1941: Schwabach bombed in [[World War II]] *1945: American military base established in Schwabach. *1953: City coat-of-arms introduced. *1972: Schwabach became an autonomous administrative district. *1975: Partner-city relationship with [[Les Sables d'Olonne]] established. *1980: Schwabach receives the European Union prize for cultural heritage. *1992: US Army to be withdrawn from Schwabach and surrounding areas. *2004: 500-year anniversary celebration of the gold foil industry. ==Sons and daughters of the town== ===Politicians=== * [[Hans Schuberth]] (born April 5, 1897, died September 2, 1976 in Munich), politician (CSU), Federal Minister for affairs of telecommunication * [[Karl Freller]] (born March 2, 1956), Member of the Bavarian Parliament (CSU) ===Athletes=== * [[Matthias Volz]] (born 4 May 1910 in Schwabach; died 26 August 2004 in Spalt), Turner, artistic gymnast Olympic champion (team) and bronze medalist in Berlin in 1936, TV 1848 Schwabach * [[Manfred Ritschel]] (born June 7, 1946), football player ===Scientists=== * [[Bernhard Grill]] (born January 5, 1961), involved in the development of [[mp3]] - format ===Artists=== * [[Walter Zimmermann]] (born April 15, 1949), composer ==Twin towns== :{{Flagicon|FRA}} [[Les Sables-d'Olonne]], France :{{Flagicon|TUR}} [[Kemer]], Turkey :{{Flagicon|GRC}} [[Kalambaka]], Greece ==Companies== * [[Apollo-Optik]], optics company ==References== {{Reflist}} {{commons category|Schwabach}} {{Germany_districts_bavaria}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Historic Jewish communities]]

{{Update|date=December 2016}} [[File:Skopje 2014 - Museum of the Macedonian Struggle and National Theatre.JPG|thumb|500px|View of the buildings finished after the 1963 earthquake (2014).]] '''Skopje 2014''' ({{lang-mk|Скопје 2014}}) is a project financed by the [[Government of the Republic of Macedonia]], with the main ideology being based on that of the then-ruling party [[VMRO-DPMNE]],<ref>EastWest Institute (2000). Jonathan P. Stein, ed. The Politics of National Minority Participation in Post-Communist Europe: State-Building, Democracy, and Ethnic Mobilization. M.E. Sharpe. p. 91. {{ISBN|978-0-7656-0528-3}}.</ref> with the purpose of giving the capital [[Skopje]] a more classical appeal. The project, officially announced in 2010, consists mainly of the construction of colleges, museums and government buildings, as well as the erection of monuments depicting historical figures from the [[Macedonia (region)|region of Macedonia]]. Around 20 buildings and over 40 monuments are planned to be constructed as part of the project.<ref name="Marusic2" />
In fact this political project is [[nation-building]] one and tries to impose a new [[Macedonian historiography|revisionist narrative of the Macedonian history]], promoting Macedonian identity, with unbroken continuity from the antiquity over the middle ages to the modern times.<ref>Janev, G. (2015). ‘Skopje 2014’: erasing memories, building history. In M. Couroucli, & T. Marinov (Eds.), Balkan heritages: Negotiating history and culture (pp. 111-130). Taylor & Francis, 2017, {{ISBN|1134800754}}.</ref> The Skopje 2014 project has been criticized by various groups since the time it was first announced for constructing nationalistic [[Historicism (art)|historicist]] [[kitsch]].<ref>Maria Couroucli and Tchavdar Marinov eds., Balkan Heritages: Negotiating History and Culture, British School at Athens - Modern Greek and Byzantine Studies, Taylor & Francis, 2017, {{ISBN|1134800754}}, p. 218.</ref> Skopje 2014 has also generated controversy for its cost, for which estimates range from 80 to 500 million euros.<ref name="Bugjevac">{{cite news|url=http://www.globusmagazin.com.mk/?ItemID=C18D740B2343534A8B173AAD06639F3A|title=СКОПЈЕ ЌЕ УМРЕ ОД НЕВКУС|last=Bugjevac|first=Dejan|year=2007|work=Globus|language=Macedonian|accessdate=8 June 2012}}</ref><ref name="Koteska">{{cite news|url=http://www.artmargins.com/index.php/2-articles/655-troubles-with-history-skopje-2014|title=Troubles with History: Skopje 2014|last=Koteska|first=Jasna|date=29 December 2011|work=Art Margins Online|accessdate=8 June 2012|location=Republic of Macedonia}}</ref>
The Skopje 2014 project encompasses the construction, from 2010 to 2014, of 136 structures built at a cost of more than US$700 million.<ref>The New York Times International Edition, October 14, 2016, pg. 19</ref>
In February 2018, the authorities and institutions of the country announced the halt of the project and then set up a Commission for envisaging the removal of its controversial monuments and statues.{{Cn|date=October 2018}}
{{Multiple image | align = right | direction = vertical | width = 250 | image1 = MacedoniaSquareSkopje edit.jpg | caption1 = | image2 = Skopje X44.JPG | caption2 = [[Macedonia Square, Skopje|Macedonia Square]] before the commencement of Skopje 2014 (top) and after the addition of many monuments and façade reconstructions (bottom) }}
==Background== [[File:Skopje-razglednica 014.jpg|thumb|250px|The National Theatre and Kale Fortress before the 1963 earthquake]] [[File:Wodno.jpg|thumb|250px|View toward [[Macedonia Square, Skopje|Macedonia Square]] from the [[Stone Bridge (Skopje)|Stone Bridge]] in July 2011. Visible are the statues of Dame Gruev, Goce Delčev, Tsar Samuil, and the under construction Warrior on a Horse monument]]
The [[1963 Skopje earthquake]] destroyed approximately 80% of the city, including most of the neoclassical buildings in the central part of Skopje.<ref name="MRT">[http://www.mrt.com.mk/en//index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=3316&Itemid=27 Marking the 44th anniversary of the catastrophic 1963 Skopje earthquake] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930210952/http://www.mrt.com.mk/en//index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=3316&Itemid=27 |date=2007-09-30 }} [[Macedonian Radio-Television|MRT]], Thursday, 26 July 2007</ref> The rebuilding that followed saw the construction of mostly plain [[modernist architecture]]. This is one of the reasons given by the VMRO-DPMNE government for the necessity of the project, to give Skopje a more monumental and visually pleasing image. Another reason is to restore the missing sense of national pride and create a more metropolitan atmosphere.<ref name="Marusic">{{cite news|url=http://www.balkaninsight.com/en/gallery/skopje-2014|title=Skopje 2014: The new face of Macedonia, updated|last=Marusic|first=Siniša|date=11 May 2012|publisher=BalkanInsight|accessdate=27 July 2012|location=Skopje}}</ref> In a speech at the opening of [[Porta Macedonia]] in January 2012, then Prime Minister [[Nikola Gruevski]] stated that Skopje 2014 was his idea.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://macedoniaonline.eu/content/view/20045/45/|title=PM Gruevski: Yes, Skopje 2014 was my Idea|date=7 January 2012|publisher=MINA|accessdate=30 July 2012}}</ref>
===Criticism=== {{see also|Antiquization}} The Skopje 2014 project has been criticized by various groups since the time it was first announced. The cost of the project is estimated at anywhere from 80 to more than 500 million euros<ref>[http://edition.cnn.com/2011/10/04/world/europe/macedonia-skopje-2014/index.html Is Macedonia's capital being turned into a theme park?], CNN, October 10, 2011</ref><ref>[http://www.balkaninsight.com/en/article/macedonian-culture-strategy-milestone-or-wish-list Macedonian Culture Strategy: Milestone or Wish List?], BalkanInsight, 15 Nov 12</ref> and is seen by many as a waste of resources in a country with high unemployment and poverty. The project is also believed by critics to be a distraction from these problems.<ref name="Marusic" />
The [[Social Democratic Union of Macedonia]], the main opposition party, opposes the project and has alleged that the monuments could have cost six to ten times less than what the government paid.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.skopjediem.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=9407:sdsm-allegations-at-government-on-skopje-2014-project-&catid=1:latest-news&Itemid=81|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130104174531/http://www.skopjediem.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=9407:sdsm-allegations-at-government-on-skopje-2014-project-&catid=1:latest-news&Itemid=81|dead-url=yes|archive-date=4 January 2013|title=SDSM Allegations at Government on Skopje 2014 Project|date=30 March 2011|publisher=SkopjeDiem|accessdate=30 July 2012|location=Skopje}}</ref>
The project is seen as a part of the government's "antiquisation" policy, in which the country seeks to claim [[Ancient Macedonians|ancient Macedonian]] figures like [[Alexander the Great]] and [[Philip II of Macedon]] for itself. The timing of the project, following the country's non-invitation to NATO due to its continued [[Macedonia naming dispute|naming dispute]] with [[Greece]], has led to speculation that it is retaliation or an attempt to put pressure on Greece.<ref name="Georgievski">''Ghosts of the past endanger Macedonia's future''. Boris Georgievski, BalkanInsight, October 27, 2009 [http://www.balkaninsight.com/en/article/ghosts-of-the-past-endanger-macedonia-s-future].</ref> Some residents see the scheme as the embodiment of nationalism by a conservative government focused as much on giving the metropolis a facelift as changing the nation's history and have described it as a mini-[[Las Vegas]]<ref>The Guardian, [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/aug/14/alexander-great-macedonia-warrior-horse Macedonia statue: Alexander the Great or a warrior on a horse?], Sunday 14 August 2011</ref> while others appreciate its classical nod to the past.<ref>[http://www.euronews.com/2011/05/05/the-changing-face-of-skopje/ The Changing Face of Skopje], Euronews.com, May 5, 2011</ref>
[[Sam Vaknin]], a former adviser to Nikola Gruevski, has stated that the project is not anti-Greek or anti-Bulgarian, but anti-Albanian. In an interview, he said "Antiquisation has a double goal, which is to marginalise the Albanians and create an identity that will not allow Albanians to become Macedonians."<ref name="Georgievski" /> The project, however, later included depictions of ethnic Albanians in the monuments including [[Nexhat Agolli]], [[Josif Bageri]], and [[Pjetër Bogdani]], as well as others on the [[Art Bridge]], and includes the construction of [[Skanderbeg Square (Skopje)|Skanderbeg Square]].
Architects have criticized the aesthetics of the project and believe the money could have been spent on constructing modern buildings.<ref name="Marusic" /> It has also been described as nationalist [[kitsch]]<ref>{{cite news|url=http://balkans.courriers.info/spip.php?page=dossier&id_article=18171|title=Macédoine : Skopje 2014, kitsch nationaliste et foire aux antiquités|year=2012|publisher=Le Courrier des Balkans|language=French|accessdate=30 July 2012}}</ref> which "brings unknown history" to the citizens<ref>Borian Jovanovski Al Jazeera, 18 March 2015, [http://www.aljazeera.com/programmes/peopleandpower/2015/03/macedonia-facade-150318135440964.html]: "Talking about this project Skopje 2014, yes it's damaging to inter-ethnic relations, it's not reflecting the multi-cultural society that Macedonia is. But on the other hand you have an Albanian party in the government - and they agree - so in a way they have responsibility for what's going on too. It's obvious that it is damaging inter-ethnic relations which are anyway fragile and damaging Macedonian national identity too because it brings us to history that is unknown to us, in which we are a kind of successor to Alexander the Great. This is not true because Alexander the Great is famous because he enlarged the Hellenic culture. We are Slavs who are not Hellenic at all."</ref> and current prime minister [[Zoran Zaev]] has labeled it an "idiotic project".<ref>Zoran Zaev, Süddeutsche Zeitung, 27 December 2016, [http://www.sueddeutsche.de/politik/mazedonien-hinter-neuen-fassaden-1.3311464]: "Mit dem idiotischen Skopje-2014-Projekt und der zusammenhängenden Pseudo-Geschichtsschreibung, die Alexander den Großen für Mazedonien reklamiert, haben wir nicht nur Griechenland provoziert, sondern auch viel internationale Unterstützung für unsere Position verloren." (English translation: With the idiotic Skopje 2014 project and the related pseudo-historiography that claims Alexander the Great for Macedonia, we have not only provoked Greece, but also lost much international support for our position.)</ref>
===2018=== In late February 2018, the government and institutions of the Republic of Macedonia announced the halt of the Skopje 2014 program and begun removing its [[Macedonian nationalism|controversial]] monuments and statues. The [[Ministry of Culture (Macedonia)|Macedonian Ministry of Culture]] also has set up a Commission to envisage the possibility of removing the rest of them, such as of [[Alexander the Great]] and [[Philip II of Macedon]]. As a first step, the monument of [[Andon Kyoseto]] was dismantled, as one of the mostly disputed of the project.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.mia.mk/EN/Inside/RenderSingleNews/289/134124689/|title=City of Skopje starting to take action on Skopje 2014 project: Mayor|publisher=Macedonian Information Agency|accessdate=9 March 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.balkaneu.com/a-skopje-2014-monument-is-removed/|title=A “Skopje 2014” monument is removed|publisher=IBNA|accessdate=9 March 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.euscoop.com/en/2018/2/22/statue-removed-macedonia|title=Macedonia Removes the Skopje 2014 Statue of Andon Kyoseto|publisher=EUscoop|accessdate=9 March 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.amna.gr/en/article/232954/Skopje-starts-removal-of-irredentist-statues-put-up-by-Gruevski-government|title=Skopje starts removal of 'irredentist' statues put up by Gruevski government|publisher=AMNA|accessdate=9 March 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.balkaneu.com/removal-of-monuments-in-skopje-whose-turn-is-next/|title=Removal of monuments in Skopje, whose turn is next?|publisher=IBNA|accessdate=9 March 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://en.protothema.gr/skopje-authorities-start-to-tear-down-nationalistic-statues/|title=Skopje authorities start to tear down nationalistic statues|publisher=Proto Thema|accessdate=9 March 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.balkaninsight.com/en/article/macedonia-removes-divisive-court-statue-02-22-2018|title=Divisive Revolutionary's Statue Vanishes from Macedonian Capital|publisher=BIRN|accessdate=9 March 2018}}</ref> In June 2018 the Macedonian Government announced that the monuments would be renamed and marked with inscriptions honouring Greek-Macedonian friendship. <ref> {{cite news|url=http://www.balkaninsight.com/en/article/divisive-skopje-2014-landmarks-find-new-purpose-06-14-2018|title=Macedonia to Rename Divisive Statues that Irked Greece|publisher=BIRN|accessdate=25 September 2018}}</ref>
==Plans==
===Bridges===
====New bridge constructions====
=====Art Bridge=====
{{main|Art Bridge}}
The Skopje 2014 project calls for two new pedestrian bridges to be built across the [[Vardar River|Vardar]] in the centre of the city. One is the Art Bridge, which is being constructed between the Freedom Bridge and the also under-construction Eye Bridge. It is expected to cost 2.5 million euros. The bridge will include 29 sculptures, with 14 at each end and one in the centre. It will be 83 metres (272.3 feet) in length and 9.2 m (30.2 ft) in width, while the central part of the bridge will be 12 m (39.4 ft) wide.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://utrinski.com.mk/default.asp?ItemID=C71B15A20E1CA24AABF563D72712711D|title=Мостот на уметноста се искачи на конструкцијата|date=April 8, 2012|publisher=Utrinski Vesnik|language=Macedonian|accessdate=19 June 2012|location=Skopje|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120613224413/http://www.utrinski.com.mk/default.asp?ItemID=C71B15A20E1CA24AABF563D72712711D|archivedate=13 June 2012|df=}}</ref>
=====Eye Bridge===== The other bridge being constructed as part of the project is the Eye Bridge. Situated between the [[Stone Bridge (Skopje)|Stone Bridge]] and the under-construction Art Bridge, it began construction in 2011. The pedestrian bridge will include 28 sculptures and will cost around 1.5 million euros.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://daily.mk/skopje-mostot-oko-konechno-pochna-da-se-gradi?forward=802275|title=Мостот Око конечно почна да се гради|date=July 29, 2011|publisher=Daily.mk|language=Macedonian|accessdate=19 June 2012|location=Skopje}}</ref>
====Existing bridge renovations====
=====Freedom Bridge===== [[File:Puente Goce Delcev, Skopie, Macedonia, 2014-04-16, DD 52.JPG|thumb|250px|Aerial view of the renovated Goce Delčev Bridge]]
The project also includes plans to renovate existing bridges in central Skopje, one of which is the Freedom Bridge, which connects Vojvoda Vasil Adžilarski Street in [[Centar Municipality (Skopje)|Centar Municipality]] to Stiv Naumov Street in [[Čair Municipality]]. First constructed in 1936, the renovation began in 2011 and is expected to be completed in May, 2014. The total cost will be roughly 1.15 million euros.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kirilica.com.mk/vest.asp?id=69962|title=1.140.000 евра за оградата на мостот кај Холидеј Ин|date=May 9, 2012|publisher=Кирилица|language=Macedonian|accessdate=2012-06-12}}</ref>
=====Goce Delčev Bridge===== The renovation of the Goce Delčev Bridge, which connects Ilinden Boulevard in Centar to Goce Delčev Boulevard in Čair across the Vardar, began on April 11, 2011<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.build.mk/?p=7238|title="Барокна" ограда за мостот Гоце Делчев|date=4 November 2011|publisher=build.mk|language=Macedonian|accessdate=12 June 2012}}</ref> and finished later in the year. The renovation included new gold-coloured fencing and 26 lampposts. The project cost roughly 500,000 euros, including 60,000 euros for the new lighting.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.build.mk/?p=10183|title=Мостот Гоце Делчев во ново светло|date=23 October 2011|publisher=build.mk|language=Macedonian|accessdate=12 June 2012}}</ref> Four statues depicting lions, two at each end, were also placed on the bridge in 2010. The ones on the western side were cast in [[Florence]] and cost 1.5 million euros.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.build.mk/?p=4837|title=Поставени два лава на мостот Гоце Делчев|date=24 August 2010|publisher=build.mk|language=Macedonian|accessdate=12 June 2012}}</ref>
=====Revolution Bridge===== The Revolution Bridge, first built in 1963 across the Vardar connecting Kočo Racin Boulevard in Centar to Krste Misirkov Boulevard in Čair, was also renovated as part of the Skopje 2014 project. It began on December 9, 2010 and was completed in May, 2011. The renovation included basic repairs as well as the installation of 22 lampposts and iron-wrought fencing. The renovation cost 450,000 euros.<ref name="сител">{{cite web|url=http://www.sitel.com.mk/dnevnik/makedonija/pushten-vo-upotreba-rekonstruiraniot-%E2%80%9Emost-na-revolucijata%E2%80%9C|title=Пуштен во употреба реконструираниот "Мост на Револуцијата"|last=Бошковска|first=Елена|date=May 16, 2011|publisher=Сител|language=Macedonian|accessdate=2012-06-12}}</ref>
===Cultural buildings===
====Macedonian Philharmonic Orchestra hall==== Notable in Skopje 2014 for its bold modern architecture as opposed to the usual neoclassical style seen in the project, the under-construction concert hall to house the Macedonian Philharmonic Orchestra is one of the first buildings to begin construction in the project, with the cornerstone having been laid in June 2009. The exterior of the building is nearing completion. The concert hall is planned to have excellent acoustics and will have a capacity of 900 seats.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://kurir.mk/makedonija/kultura/49599-FOTO-Kako-ke-izgleda-novata-sala-na-Makedonskata-Filharmonija|title=ФОТО: Како ќе изгледа новата сала на Македонската Филхармонија?|date=14 November 2011|publisher=Kurir|language=Macedonian|accessdate=5 July 2012|location=Skopje|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120220164605/http://www.kurir.mk/makedonija/kultura/49599-FOTO-Kako-ke-izgleda-novata-sala-na-Makedonskata-Filharmonija|archivedate=20 February 2012|df=}}</ref>
====Museum of Archaeology==== [[File:MuseumofArchaeologySkopje.jpg|thumb|220px|The completed Museum of Archaeology]]
The Museum of Archaeology began construction in 2009 and is expected to be formally opened in September, 2014.<ref name="Vasilevski">{{cite news|url=http://www.novamakedonija.com.mk/NewsDetal.asp?vest=491482343&id=14&setIzdanie=23147|title=Во музејот, освен археологија, ќе има и приказна за една величествена историја|last=Vasilevski|first=Žarko|publisher=Nova Makedonija|language=Macedonian|accessdate=3 May 2014}}</ref> Although the building will primarily serve as a museum, it will also house the Constitutional Court and the National Archive of the Republic of Macedonia. It is situated on the eastern bank of the [[Vardar]], across the river from [[Macedonia Square, Skopje|Macedonia Square]]. The exterior of the museum is almost complete, as of June 2012, and is among the more monumental buildings of the project, with its [[Greek Revival]] architecture.<ref name="Ivanovska">{{cite news|url=http://www.dnevnik.com.mk/?ItemID=DC1E632C696096498994678CDACAFDF6|title=Археолошки музеј во центарот на Скопје|last=Ivanovska|first=Vesna|date=January 21, 2009|work=Dnevnik|language=Macedonian|accessdate=22 June 2012|location=Skopje}}</ref> [[VMRO-DPMNE]], the ruling party, states the budget for the construction as 436,000,000 [[Macedonian denar|denars]].<ref name="VMRO-DPMNE">{{cite web|url=http://vmro-dpmne.org.mk/wp-content/uploads/documents/VMRO%20programa%202014-2018%20v2a.pdf|title=Проберено: Проекти кои што докажано се остартуваат|publisher=VMRO-DPMNE|accessdate=3 May 2014}}</ref>
====Museum of the Macedonian Struggle==== {{Multiple image | align = left | direction = vertical | width = 220 | image1 = Muzej na VMRO 016.jpg | image2 = Museo de Lucha Macedonia, Skopie, Macedonia, 2014-04-16, DD 99.JPG | footer = The completed [[Museum of the Macedonian Struggle (Skopje)|Museum of the Macedonian Struggle]] }}
{{main|Museum of the Macedonian Struggle (Skopje)}}
The Museum of the Macedonian Struggle for Statehood and Independence − Museum of VMRO and Museum of the Victims of the Communist Regime exhibits the strive for an independent Macedonian nation from the [[Ottoman Empire]] and later [[Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia|Yugoslavia]]. It is divided into 16 departments and includes over 100 wax figures of historical individuals. The museum lies on the eastern bank of the Vardar River just northwest of the Museum of Archaeology, opposite Macedonia Square. Construction began in June 2008 and it formally opened on September 10, 2011. The total cost of the museum, which covers 2,500 m<sup>2</sup> (26,909.8 ft<sup>2</sup>), was roughly 10 million euros.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.build.mk/?p=9561|title=ФОТО ВЕСТ: Свечено отворен Музејскиот комплекс "Македонска борба"|date=September 9, 2011|publisher=build.mk|language=Macedonian|accessdate=19 June 2012|location=Skopje}}</ref>
{{Multiple image | align = right | direction = vertical | width = 220 | image1 = Makedonski Naroden Teatar 2013 15.JPG | image2 = Teatro Nacional, Skopie, Macedonia, 2014-04-17, DD 93.JPG | footer = The completed National Theatre }}
====National Theatre==== The former National Theatre destroyed in the [[1963 Skopje earthquake]] will be completely reconstructed, as part of the Skopje 2014 project. Construction of the building, however, began in December 2007, three years before the official announcing of Skopje 2014. Construction was originally planned to be completed in 2009, though it ended up being completed a few years after.<ref name="Factor">{{cite news|url=http://faktor.mk/archives/102033|title=Стариот театар уште "голта" пари|date=10 April 2014|publisher=Factor|language=Macedonian|accessdate=3 May 2014}}</ref> The theatre stands on its original location on the eastern bank of the Vardar. The cost is estimated to be at least 6 million euros<ref name="Mitevska">{{cite news|url=http://www.utrinski.com.mk/?ItemID=EB377439F9568B45B8D60B595B5C157E|title=Започна изградбата на новиот МНТ|last=Mitevska|first=Liljana|date=7 December 2007|publisher=Utrinski Vesnik|language=Macedonian|accessdate=5 July 2012|location=Skopje}}</ref> and may be as high as 30 million euros.<ref name="Marusic2">{{cite news|url=http://balkanstory.wordpress.com/2012/06/07/skopje-2014-forges-ahead-despite-macedonian-crisis/|title=Skopje 2014 Forges Ahead Despite Macedonian Crisis|last=Marusic|first=Sinisa|publisher=Balkan Story|accessdate=30 July 2012|location=Skopje}}</ref>
===Façade reconstructions=== [[File:SkopjeNewFaçades.jpg|thumb|220px|Reconstructed façades near Macedonia Square]]
The Skopje 2014 project also includes plans to transform the façades of existing buildings in central Skopje into the neoclassical style. This includes the following buildings:
*Buildings along Dimitrija Čupovski Street<ref name="build.mk5">{{cite news|url=http://www.build.mk/?p=13047|title=Целиот строг центар на Скопје ќе добие нови фасади|date=6 March 2012|publisher=build.mk|language=Macedonian|accessdate=5 July 2012|location=Skopje}}</ref> *Buildings along Macedonia Street<ref name="build.mk5" /> *Buildings along Nikola Vapcarov Street<ref name="build.mk5" /> *Buildings around Macedonia Square<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.build.mk/?p=14739|title=Продолжува промената на фасадите околу Плоштадот Македонија|date=3 May 2012|publisher=build.mk|language=Macedonian|accessdate=5 July 2012|location=Skopje}}</ref> *City Trade Center<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.build.mk/?p=15922|title=ГТЦ ќе добие нова фасада и надградба|date=14 June 2012|publisher=build.mk|language=Macedonian|accessdate=5 July 2012|location=Skopje}}</ref> *Department of Transport and Communications Building, located on Karpoš's Rebellion Square.<ref name="http">{{cite news|url=http://www.build.mk/?p=8540|title=Почнува уредувањето на плоштадот Карпошово востание|publisher=build.mk|language=Macedonian|accessdate=28 June 2012|location=Skopje}}</ref> *[[Government of the Republic of Macedonia]] building. The new façade appearance choice for this building was made by the Macedonian public through online votes on the government's website. There were five choices and the neoclassical choice won a plurality.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.build.mk/?p=13541|title=Во мај проект, а летово и тендер за менување на ликот на владината зграда|date=22 March 2012|publisher=build.mk|language=Macedonian|accessdate=5 July 2012|location=Skopje}}</ref> *MEPSO Building, located north of Macedonia Square.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.build.mk/?p=12950|title=И главната зграда на МЕПСО со класицистичка фасада|date=2 March 2012|publisher=build.mk|language=Macedonian|accessdate=5 July 2012|location=Skopje}}</ref> *Ministry of Justice building<ref name="Vasilevski">{{cite news|url=http://architect.mk/konkursi/824-konkurs-rekonstrukcija-i-adaptacija-za-objekt-upravna-zgrada-na-ministerstvo-za-pravda-skopje|title=Конкурс - Реконструкција и адаптација на фасада за објект Управна зграда на Министерство за правда во Скопје|last=Vasilevski|first=Igor|date=3 August 2010|publisher=Architect.mk|language=Macedonian|accessdate=5 July 2012}}</ref> *[[Parliament of the Republic of Macedonia|Parliament]] building. The renovation of the Parliament also includes the construction of cupolas atop the building.<ref name="Smilevska">{{cite news|url=http://vesti.alfa.mk/default.aspx?mid=36&eventid=9125|title=Отворени тендерите за реконструкција на Собранието|last=Smilevska|first=Milka|date=15 June 2009|publisher=Alfa TV|language=Macedonian|accessdate=5 July 2012|location=Skopje}}</ref>
===Government buildings=== The following are new buildings being constructed to house various governmental functions.
====Agency for Electronic Communications==== [[File:Skopje 2014 - Agency for Electronic Communications and Archeological Museum.JPG|thumb|Agency for Electronic Communications (right)]] The cornerstone for the new building to house the Agency for Electronic Communications was laid on 30 March 2011. It is being constructed on the eastern bank of the Vardar in between two other Skopje 2014 buildings, the Museum of Archaeology and the Financial Police Building.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.build.mk/?p=7083|title=Камен темелник за новиот објект на АЕК|date=30 March 2011|publisher=build.mk|language=Macedonian|accessdate=2 July 2012|location=Skopje}}</ref>
The total cost of the building's construction is around 8.5 million euros, which the government claims will be fully funded by the Agency's budget. It is expected to be completed in 15 months or by the late summer of 2012.<ref name="Jovanova">{{cite news|url=http://www.kapital.mk/MK/dneven_vesnik.aspx/26429/agencijata_za_elektronski_komunikacii_ja_dobiva_svojata_zgrada.aspx?iId=33|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130221020103/http://www.kapital.mk/MK/dneven_vesnik.aspx/26429/agencijata_za_elektronski_komunikacii_ja_dobiva_svojata_zgrada.aspx?iId=33|dead-url=yes|archive-date=21 February 2013|title=АГЕНЦИЈАТА ЗА ЕЛЕКТРОНСКИ КОМУНИКАЦИИ ЈА ДОБИВА СВОЈАТА ЗГРАДА|last=Jovanova|first=Sonja|date=30 March 2011|publisher=Kapital|language=Macedonian|accessdate=2 July 2012|location=Skopje}}</ref>
====Criminal Court Building==== A new Criminal Court Building is being constructed as part of the project. The cornerstone for the building was laid on 25 May 2010. The building, 10 stories tall, has been topped out. In it will be 74 judicial offices, 22 high courts, and 2 large courtrooms. The 2-story basement will contain parking. The building, reported to cost 8.3 million euros, was planned to be completed after 18 months of construction.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.build.mk/?p=3626|title=Поставен камен темелник за новиот Кривичен суд|date=29 May 2010|publisher=build.mk|language=Macedonian|accessdate=3 July 2012|location=Skopje}}</ref>
====Financial Police Building==== [[File:MFAandFinancialPoliceBldgSkopje.jpg|220px|thumb|The completed Financial Police and Ministry of Foreign Affairs buildings]] On 11 October 2010 the cornerstone for the new building to house the Financial Police of the Republic of Macedonia was laid. The site is located between the new Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the new Agency for Electronic Communications. The building, currently several months from completion, is cylindrical in shape and is capped by a dome-shaped roof. The total cost of construction will be roughly 13 million euros.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.build.mk/?p=5216|title=Камен темелник за зграда на Обвинителството и Финансиската полиција|publisher=build.mk|language=Macedonian|accessdate=4 July 2012|location=Skopje}}</ref>
====Ministry of Finance==== The government, in March 2011, invested 8.9 million euros into transforming an abandoned uncompleted building in central Skopje into a new home for the Ministry of Finance. Like the other governmental buildings in Skopje 2014, it will have a neoclassical appearance. Though it was scheduled to be completed in the first quarter of 2012, the building remains far from completion.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.build.mk/?p=6871|title=Министерството за финансии ќе се сели во "Југобанка"|date=8 March 2011|publisher=build.mk|language=Macedonian|accessdate=4 July 2012|location=Skopje}}</ref>
====Ministry of Foreign Affairs==== Construction of the new Ministry of Foreign Affairs building began in January 2010. It is located on the eastern bank of the Vardar between the Financial Police Building and Stiv Naumov Street. It will have two basement levels, seven above-ground levels, and a terrace atop the building. The building, which is nearly complete on the exterior, stands at a height of 27 m (88.6 ft) and will have costed 13.5 million euros when completed.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.build.mk/?p=2837|title=Официјален камен темелник за новото МНР|publisher=build.mk|language=Macedonian|accessdate=4 July 2012|location=Skopje}}</ref>
====New City Hall==== A new city hall for Skopje is being constructed below the [[Skopje Fortress|Kale Fortress]], on the eastern bank of the Vardar. It is being constructed, as most other buildings in the project, in the neoclassical style and will cost roughly 15 million euros. It will be 21 m (68.9 ft) tall, with six above-ground floors.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.build.mk/?p=7984|title=Се гради објект за скопската градска администрација|date=3 June 2011|publisher=build.mk|language=Macedonian|accessdate=5 July 2012|location=Skopje}}</ref>
====Old City Hall==== Although a new city hall for Skopje is being constructed, the former one destroyed in the [[1963 Skopje earthquake]] will be fully reconstructed, as part of the Skopje 2014 project. It will be built on its original location at the north side of Macedonia Square, to the west of the Vardar Quay. A Greek investor will be building the Old City Hall, as well as a Marriott Hotel to the immediate left of the building, after purchasing the land in March 2011.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.build.mk/?p=6920|title=Грчки инвеститор ќе ги гради Офицерскиот дом и хотелот на Плоштад Македонија|date=12 March 2011|publisher=build.mk|language=Macedonian|accessdate=5 July 2012|location=Skopje}}</ref>
====Water Management Building==== Among the buildings being constructed below the [[Skopje Fortress|Kale Fortress]] on the eastern bank of the Vardar is the Water Management Building. Construction of the building began in December 2011. It is expected to be completed in 3 years at a cost of 10 million euros.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.time.mk/read/58d92cc11d/d4bf718890/index.html|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130221032952/http://www.time.mk/read/58d92cc11d/d4bf718890/index.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=21 February 2013|title=Поставен камен-темелник на новата зграда на ЈП "Водовод и канализација"|date=4 December 2011|publisher=[[Macedonian Radio-Television]]|language=Macedonian|accessdate=5 July 2012|location=Skopje}}</ref><ref name="Trajkovska">{{cite news|url=http://www.utrinski.com.mk/?ItemID=6C30BE3B498BB14E96CAE30F422EF3AF|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130219022739/http://www.utrinski.com.mk/?ItemID=6C30BE3B498BB14E96CAE30F422EF3AF|dead-url=yes|archive-date=19 February 2013|title=Градската администрација ќе добие зграда под Кале|last=Trajkovska|first=Despina|date=13 December 2010|publisher=Utrinski Vesnik|language=Macedonian|accessdate=5 July 2012|location=Skopje}}</ref>
===Monuments===
====Justinian I==== [[File:Justinian I . 2 . Monuments in Skopje.JPG|thumb|180px|Justinian I monument]]
The monument of [[Justinian I]], born in [[Tauresium]] just outside modern Skopje, arrived at Macedonia Square on June 16, 2011. Similar to the monument of Tsar Samuil, also on Macedonia Square, it consists of Justinian I sitting on a throne, which is placed on a pedestal. The monument is made of white marble with the exception of the bronze reliefs on the pedestal, also characteristics it shares with the Tsar Samuil monument. The pedestal is 3.5 m (11.5 ft) tall, while Justinian upon his throne measures a further 5 m (16.4 ft) in height.
The monument sits just north of the Stone Bridge, at the western bank of the Vardar River. It was made in Florence and cost over 1 million euros.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sky.mk/component/content/article/1249-2011-06-17-11-56-48.html|title=Се поставува Јустинијан Први|date=17 June 2011 <!--13:55-->|publisher=Sky.mk|language=Macedonian|accessdate=2011-06-18|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140203085300/http://sky.mk/component/content/article/1249-2011-06-17-11-56-48.html|archivedate=3 February 2014|df=}}</ref>
====Mother Teresa==== The construction of a monument consisting of a statue of Skopje native [[Mother Teresa]] and a fountain is planned. The monument will be located near the MEPSO building, which is north of Macedonia Square near the Vardar Quay, though location on the roundabout near the Goce Delčev Bridge is also a possibility. It is planned to stand around 30 m (98.4 ft) in height, even taller than the Warrior on a Horse monument.
It has been reported that a donation from India will fund the construction of the new Mother Teresa monument, who is already memorialized in the city with the [[Memorial House of Mother Teresa]] and a plaque marking the spot of her birth.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://bukvar.mk/news/kje-se-gradi-spomenik-na-majka-tereza-povisok-od-voinot-na-konj?newsid=9SxW|title=ЌЕ СЕ ГРАДИ СПОМЕНИК НА МАЈКА ТЕРЕЗА ПОВИСОК ОД ВОИНОТ НА КОЊ|date=29 June 2012|publisher=Fakulteti.mk|language=Macedonian|accessdate=30 June 2012|location=Skopje}}</ref>
====Pavilion at Macedonia Square==== [[File:Летниковецот на Плоштад (8).JPG|thumb|left|200px|The Pavilion at Macedonia Square]]
The Pavilion at Macedonia Square is situated on the north side of Macedonia Square. Construction began in early 2011 and was completed later that year at a cost of 350,000 euros.<ref name="Dimitrievski">{{cite news|url=http://daily.mk/i-letnikovec?forward=567090|title=И летниковец ...|last=Dimitrievski|first=Aleksandar|date=26 January 2011|publisher=Alfa TV|language=Macedonian|accessdate=23 June 2012|location=Skopje}}</ref> The pavilion consists of a dome supported by several columns, covering a statue of a romantic couple.
====Porta Macedonia==== [[File:Porta Makedonija 02.JPG|thumb|220px|[[Porta Macedonia]]]] {{Main|Porta Macedonia}}
One of the main symbols of the project is Porta Macedonia, a [[triumphal arch]] situated on 11 October Street, near Macedonia Square. The arch is meant to commemorate the long struggle for Macedonian independence. It is 21 m (68.9 ft) tall and contains 32 reliefs carved on the outside, depicting events from pre-history to the independence of the Republic of Macedonia. The inside of the arch consists of two levels, in which a souvenir shop and a gallery are located, and a rooftop observation deck. It formally opened to the public on Christmas Eve, January 6, 2012. The construction of Porta Macedonia is estimated at 4.5 million euros.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.build.mk/?p=11623|title="Порта Македонија" свечено претставена на јавноста|date=January 6, 2012|publisher=build.mk|language=Macedonian|accessdate=22 June 2012|location=Skopje}}</ref>
====Tsar Samuil==== [[File:Samuil 1. Monuments in Skopje.JPG|thumb|left|180px|Tsar Samuil monument]]
The monument to [[Samuel of Bulgaria]] is among the new focal points of Macedonia Square. Officially unveiled on 28 June 2011, it is situated in front of the Pelister building, to the right of where Macedonia Street meets Macedonia Square.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.a1.com.mk/vesti/default.aspx?VestID=139834|title=Поставен споменикот на Цар Самоил|date=2011-06-28 <!-- 15:23 --> |publisher=А1|language=Macedonian|accessdate=2011-07-31}}</ref>
The monument, mostly in white marble, consists of a depiction of Tsar Samuil sitting on a throne, totaling 5 m (16.4 ft) in height, and is placed on a pedestal which itself is a further 3.5 m (11.5 ft) tall. The reliefs on the sides of the pedestal are bronze. Tsar Samuil, in the monument, holds a scepter. Made in Florence, the total cost of the Tsar Samuil monument was roughly 3.5 million euros.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dnevnik.com.mk/default.asp?ItemID=E96A2FA4FAECB34697607E35AE088F1A|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130219045443/http://www.dnevnik.com.mk/default.asp?ItemID=E96A2FA4FAECB34697607E35AE088F1A|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2013-02-19|title=Споменикот на Цар Самоил стигна на плоштадот "Македонија"|date=2011-06-28 <!-- , 11:11 -->|publisher=Dnevnik|language=Macedonian|accessdate=2011-07-31}}</ref>
The [[fringe theory]] Samuil being the first Tsar of the Macedonian Slavs is held mainly in the Republic of Macedonia.<ref>An outline of Macedonian history from ancient times to 1991. Macedonian Embassy London. Retrieved on 2007-04-28.</ref> This view is ahistorical, as it projects modern ethnic distinctions into the past.<ref>The Oxford Dictionary of Byzantium, Vol 1, New York-Oxford, Oxford University Press, 1991 (p. 1838)</ref>
====Warrior monument==== {{Multiple image | align = right | direction = horizontal | width = 150 | image1 = Skopje - Warrior Monument.jpg | caption1 = | image2 = Воинот со фонтана (6).JPG | footer = Warrior monument }} On the opposite side of the Stone Bridge from Macedonia Square is Karpoš's Rebellion Square, which serves as a main entrance to the [[Old Bazaar, Skopje|Old Bazaar]]. It is undergoing a major reconstruction, as part of Skopje 2014, and its new centerpiece will be the statue and fountain officially named "Warrior," though it is widely believed that the statue is a depiction of [[Philip II of Macedon]], not to be confused with the equestrian statue of Philip II in Skopje's Avtokomanda neighborhood. The statue was placed onto the square on 22 May 2012.
Made in Vicenza, the statue is 15 m (49.2 ft) tall and is placed on a 13 m (42.7 ft) tall pedestal. The entire monument will cost roughly 2 million euros.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.build.mk/?p=15338|title=Филип Втори поставен на плоштадот "Карпошово востание"|date=22 May 2012|publisher=build.mk|language=Macedonian|accessdate=29 June 2012|location=Skopje}}</ref>
====Warrior on a Horse monument==== {{Multiple image | align = left | direction = horizontal | width = 150 | image1 = Aleksandar Makedonski vo Skopje 011.jpg | caption1 = | image2 = Guerrero a caballo, Skopie, Macedonia, 2014-04-17, DD 103.JPG | footer = Warrior on a Horse monument }} Perhaps the main symbol of the Skopje 2014 project is the Warrior on a Horse ({{lang-mk|Воин на коњ}}) statue and fountain in the centre of Macedonia Square. It is typically thought to depict [[Alexander the Great]], though it is not officially named for him.<ref>[http://edition.cnn.com/2011/10/04/world/europe/macedonia-skopje-2014/index.html Is Macedonia's capital being turned into a theme park?] CNN International, 10 October 2011</ref><ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/aug/14/alexander-great-macedonia-warrior-horse Macedonia statue: Alexander the Great or a warrior on a horse?] The Guardian, Sunday 14 August 2011</ref>
The statue was sculpted by [[Valentina Stevanovska]] and cast in Florence. "Alexander" was officially completed on September 8, 2011 to commemorate 20 years of the independence of the Republic of Macedonia. It is 14.5 m (47.6 ft) tall and it sits on a cylindrical column, which itself is 10 m (32.8 ft) in height. The column consists of three large ivory sections, each separated by a thinner bronze ring. Each section contains reliefs. The column stands in a fountain. At the base of the column are 8 bronze soldiers, each 3 m (9.8 ft) tall. There are also 8 bronze lions, each 2.5 m (8.3 ft) tall, around the edges of the fountain pool, four of which act as part of the fountain, releasing water from their mouths. The fountain also plays music.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://vesti.alfa.mk/default.aspx?mid=36&eventid=40603|title=Пуштање во употреба фонтана со споменикот "Воин на коњ"|date=8 September 2011|publisher=Alfa TV|language=Macedonian|accessdate=23 June 2012|location=Skopje|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120723123128/http://vesti.alfa.mk/default.aspx?mid=36&eventid=40603|archivedate=23 July 2012|df=}}</ref>
The total cost of the Warrior on a Horse monument is roughly 7.5 million euros.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.trtmacedonian.com/trtworld/mk/newsDetail.aspx?HaberKodu=a7c635ff-8af9-489b-867a-9d01e3251863|title=ПОСТАВЕН СПОМЕНИКОТ НА АЛЕКСАНДАР МАКЕДОНСКИ НАРЕЧЕН "ВОИН НА КОЊ" ВО СКОПЈЕ|publisher=www.trtmacedonian.com|accessdate=20 September 2011}}</ref>

===Miscellaneous===
====Docked boats in Vardar River==== [[File:Ship in Vardar, Skopje.jpg|thumb|200px|One of building-boats in the Vardar River]] The first of four building-boats as restaurants and cafes just in the Vardar River opened in July 2014. The boats are erected into the riverbed and, thus, will remain in their planned spots permanently. The boats, all to be situated in central Skopje, were intended to be in the Baroque style.<ref name="plusinfo1">{{cite news|url=http://www.plusinfo.mk/vest/144687/Zaplovi-prvata-galija-vo-Vardar|title="Заплови" првата галија во Вардар|date=21 July 2014|language=Macedonian|accessdate=24 July 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sitel.com.mk/dnevnik/makedonija/izbrani-idejnite-reshenija-za-splavovi-na-vardar|title=Избрани идејните решенија за сплавови на Вардар|date=3 March 2012|publisher=Sitel|language=Macedonian|accessdate=20 July 2012|location=Skopje}}</ref>
====Ferris wheel==== The erection of a Ferris wheel is foreseen on the Vardar River. It will require the construction of a new pedestrian bridge, to run from the [[Museum of the Macedonian Struggle (Skopje)|Museum of the Macedonian Struggle]] to the MEPSO Building, upon which it will stand. No final plan for the project has been approved.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.plusinfo.mk/vest/27264/Panoramskoto-trkalo-kje-se-gradi-na-nov-most|title=Панорамското тркало ќе се гради на нов мост|date=21 December 2011|publisher=Plusinfo|language=Macedonian|accessdate=8 July 2012|location=Skopje}}</ref>
====Fountains in Vardar River==== The addition of fountains on the Vardar River was planned early on in the project. They were completed in 2010. The fountains have been criticized for reportedly releasing mud, as well as for acting as a filter for trash flowing down the river.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://kirilica.com.mk/vest.asp?id=66369|title=Потскокна и фонтаната во Вардар|date=7 September 2011|publisher=Kirilica|language=Macedonian|accessdate=17 July 2012|location=Skopje}}</ref>
====Kale Fortress reconstruction==== Director of Cultural Heritage and archaeologist [[Pasko Kuzman]] has announced a plan to restore and reconstruct the [[Skopje Fortress|Kale Fortress]]. The plan also includes the construction of a museum to house Byzantine archaeological finds from the fortress, as well as reconstructions of a prehistoric house and an Ottoman guard tower to be built on the place of their ruins. Souvenir shops and cafes are also foreseen additions. The most controversial part of the restoration of the fortress is the construction of a church, which has been protested by ethnic Albanians.<ref name="Trpčevska">{{cite news|url=http://www.utrinski.com.mk/?ItemID=5CE5FDEADB1BF94B8543DC889925F25D|title=Отомански кули и праисториски куќи ќе никнат на Кале|last=Trpčevska|first=Daniela|date=24 August 2011|publisher=build.mk|language=Macedonian|accessdate=8 July 2012|location=Skopje}}</ref>
====Karpoš's Rebellion Square reconstruction==== Karpoš's Rebellion Square is situated opposite the Vardar River of Macedonia Square and is undergoing a significant reconstruction. Plans include the erection of a statue and fountain depicting Phillip II of Macedon, though officially named "Warrior," at the far northeast side of the square. Another monument consisting of a fountain and statues representing the Mothers of Macedonia is being constructed in front of the Warrior monument. In front of this will be two monuments, also consisting of a fountain and statues, depicting horses. The two will be situated on either side of the entrance to the square from the Stone Bridge.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.build.mk/?p=8540|title=Почнува уредувањето на плоштадот Карпошово востание|date=6 July 2011|publisher=build.mk|language=Macedonian|accessdate=27 July 2012|location=Skopje}}</ref>
====Office building on Macedonia Square==== [[File:OfficeBldgMacedoniaSquare.jpg|thumb|220px|The office building]]
A new office building was constructed on the south side of Macedonia Square, on the Vardar Quay. It stands on the same place as the former headquarters of the National Bank, which was destroyed in the [[1963 Skopje earthquake]]. The new office building is similar in shape to the former bank building, though it is not in the neoclassical style, which also makes it somewhat unusual in the Skopje 2014 project.<ref name="Naumovska">{{cite news|url=http://www.utrinski.com.mk/default.asp?ItemID=4048432E7DF51C4B886B49D49DB3C216|title=Новата зграда во Скопје само ќе личи на Народната банка|last=Naumovska|first=Sanja|date=8 August 2008|publisher=Utrinski Vesnik|language=Macedonian|accessdate=12 July 2012|location=Skopje}}</ref>
====Skanderbeg Square construction==== {{Main|Skanderbeg Square (Skopje)}} [[File:Skopje, Daut Pasuv hamam (turecke lazne) ve Skopji, bila budova v.jpg|thumb|220px|Macedonian Opera]] An existing statue of [[Skanderbeg]], an important historical figure to ethnic Albanians, will be the main fixture of an under construction square that will bear his name in Skopje's [[Čair Municipality]]. The square's total cost is estimated at around 10 million euros and is expected to be completed in 2014. The square will cover 28,000 m<sup>2</sup> (301,389 ft<sup>2</sup>) and will extend from Macedonian Philharmonic and Macedonian Opera to the [[Old Bazaar, Skopje|Old Bazaar]]. This will require building a portion of the square on top of Goce Delčev Boulevard. Aside from plenty of open space, the square will contain an amphitheatre, a fountain, and underground parking.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.kanal5.com.mk/default.aspx?mId=37&eventId=83549&egId=13|title="Скендер Бег" готов до 2014 - та|date=28 November 2011|publisher=build.mk|language=Macedonian|accessdate=27 July 2012|location=Skopje|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120726135632/http://kanal5.com.mk/default.aspx?mId=37|archivedate=26 July 2012|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.time.mk/read/218a743d6a/484bce79b5/index.html|title=Плоштадот Скендерг-бег ќе чини 10 милиони евра|date=21 October 2011|publisher=Time.mk|language=Macedonian|accessdate=27 July 2012|location=Skopje|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130219034051/http://www.time.mk/read/218a743d6a/484bce79b5/index.html|archivedate=19 February 2013|df=}}</ref>
[[File:Muzej na VMRO 019.JPG|thumb|220px|One of the Vardar River fountains]]
====Other==== [[File:Skopje Double deckers (cropped).jpg|thumb|220px|Double decker buses]] Other components of Skopje 2014 include the following: *202 [[double decker bus|double-decker]] city buses, like London, in city's routes. *Three willow trees planted in the Vardar River in central Skopje.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.plusinfo.mk/vest/41310/Trite-vrbi-kje-rastat-vo-Vardar-po-naredba-na-Srbija-|title=Трите врби ќе растат во Вардар по "наредба" на Србија!?|date=1 July 2008|publisher=Plusinfo|language=Macedonian|accessdate=20 July 2012|location=Skopje}}</ref> *The restoration of buildings in the historic [[Old Bazaar, Skopje|Old Bazaar]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.build.mk/?p=14551|title=Ќе се обновуваат 250 фасади на објекти со културно – историско значење|date=25 April 2012|publisher=build.mk|language=Macedonian|accessdate=27 July 2012|location=Skopje}}</ref><ref name="Ognjanov">{{cite news|url=http://www.dnevnik.com.mk/default-mk.asp?itemID=3A09BA95C0B1804BA63742A4B9927F98&arc=1|title=Почнува ревитализацијата на скопската чаршија|last=Ognjanov|first=Toše|date=17 February 2010|publisher=Dnevnik|language=Macedonian|accessdate=27 July 2012|location=Skopje|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100304095742/http://www.dnevnik.com.mk/default-mk.asp?itemID=3A09BA95C0B1804BA63742A4B9927F98&arc=1|archivedate=4 March 2010|df=}}</ref> *Hotels, including a [[Marriott Hotel]] constructed in May 2016 on Macedonia Square.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.build.mk/?p=3390|title=Скопје ќе добие Marriott Hotel|date=14 May 2010|publisher=build.mk|language=Macedonian|accessdate=27 July 2012|location=Skopje}}</ref> *Parking garages.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.build.mk/?p=15775|title="Никофон" ќе гради катна гаража во "барокен" стил спроти Старата железничка станица, "Макоил" близу плоштадот Македонија|date=7 June 2012|publisher=build.mk|language=Macedonian|accessdate=27 July 2012|location=Skopje}}</ref>

{{Expand Finnish|date=February 2009|T. I. Itkonen}} [[File:Toivo-Immanuel-Itkonen.jpg|thumb|right|T. I. Itkonen.]] '''Toivo Immanuel Itkonen''' (January 20, 1891 – May 12, 1968) was a [[Finland|Finnish]] [[historian]] and linguist, specializing in the [[Sami languages]] and the history of the [[Sami people]].
Itkonen was born in [[Pulkkila]]. Hi father, Lauri Arvid Itkonen (1865–1925), was the curate of the Lutheran church of [[Pulkkila]]. Lauri Itkonen and his six children moved to [[Inari, Finland|Inari]] during the Spring of 1899, when Lauri received the post of rector of the Inari church. It was here that Toivo first began his education with a home tutor and then in 1901, moved to [[Oulu]] to begin secondary school. He graduated from Oulu secondary school in 1910. In 1913 he graduated from the [[University of Helsinki]] with a Bachelor's degree in philosophy. In 1916 he received his Master's degree and in 1923, his Doctorate.
During 1911–1949, Itkonen made 9 research trips to [[Lapland (Finland)|Lapland]]. He also made research trips to central Europe (1929) and Scandinavia (1931 and 1934). His last research trip was to Italy, in 1955. Based on his research in [[Lapland (Finland)|Lapland]], Itkonen published the two part "The Lapps in Finland up to 1945 Vol. 1 & 2" in 1948.
Toivo Itkonen was married to Amanda Seppänen, with whom he had three children, Terho, Marja and Kerttu. He died in [[Helsinki]], aged 77.
==References== * [http://www.siida.fi/anaras/english/tutkimus/titkonen.html T.I. Itkonen], ''Anaras – The Inari Sami'', [[Siida (museum)|Siida]] website.

[[Myanmar National Literature Award|Myanma Lifetime Achievement in Literature National Literary Award]] (2010) }} '''Sithu Thaw Kaung''' ({{lang-my|သော်ကောင်း}}) is a Burmese university librarian, historian and leading authority in Asian [[library studies]].{{cite web|url=http://www.city.fukuoka.lg.jp/fu-a/en/culture_prizes/detail/71.html|title=Thaw Kaung|publisher=Fukuoka Asian Culture Prize|accessdate=20 July 2015}} He specializes in the preservation and archival of traditional documents, including [[palm leaf manuscript]]s. ==Early life== Thaw Kaung was born on 17 December 1937 in [[Rangoon]], as the eldest child of second generation [[Sino-Burmese]] parents, Sithu U Kaung (surnamed [[Su (surname)|Saw or Suu]]), and [[Burmese names|Daw]] Thein (surnamed [[Teoh or Teo]]).{{cite book|last=Suryadinata|first=Leo|title=Southeast Asian Personalities of Chinese Descent: A Biographical Dictionary|publisher=Institute of Southeast Asian Studies|date=2012|isbn=9789814345217}}{{cite web|url=http://fukuoka-prize.org/en/laureate/prize/acd/thawkaung.php|title=Thaw Kaung [ Academic Prize 2005 ]|publisher=Fukuoka Prize|accessdate=20 July 2015}} His parents were of [[Hokkien]] descent, with ancestors from [[Quanzhou]], [[Fujian]]. Thaw Kaung's father was a Director of Education from 1951 to 1957. In 1947, Thaw Kaung followed his father to England to oversee the Burmese scholars studying there. In 1950, he returned to Rangoon, but could not attend school because he suffered from [[poliarthriticsmyelitis]]. == Education == Thaw Kaung attended [[Basic Education High School No. 1 Dagon|Methodist English High School]] (now Basic Education High School No. 1 Dagon) from 1952 to 1954, passing the Matriculation examinations in the First Division with distinctions in English and Geography. He majored in English Literature at [[Rangoon University]], graduating with [[British undergraduate degree classification|First Class]] Honours in 1959.{{cite web|url=http://www.irrawaddylitfest.com/bur/u-thaw-kaung-2/|title=U Thaw Kaung|date=13 October 2013|work=Irrawaddy Literary Festival|accessdate=20 July 2015}} He won the U [[Po Hnit]] Gold Medal, which was awarded by Rangoon University to the highest-standing student in the B.A. examination for Honours English.{{cite book|title=Handbook Of Indian Universities|publisher=JHK Bangalore Press|location=Bangalore|date=1928|url=https://archive.org/stream/handbookofindian029307mbp/handbookofindian029307mbp_djvu.txt}} He was selected in 1960 as a Burma State Scholar to obtain a Postgraduate Diploma in Librarianship, specializing in Oriental Bibliography, from the [[University of London]]'s [[University College London]] in 1962. ==Professional career== He was appointed as Deputy University Librarian in 1959 and promoted as the Chief Librarian of the Universities Central Library in 1969. In 1971, he established the Department of Library Studies at the University, and was a central figure in the establishment of the Myanmar Library Association and the National Commission for the Preservation of Traditional Manuscripts. Between 1971 and 1976, he served as Secretary of the [[Myanmar Language Commission and the first Chairman of the Committee which compiled the Burmese-English Dictionary]]. Thaw Kaung was elected an Honorary Fellow of the Library Association UK in 1984, becoming the first Southeast Asian librarian to the awarded this prestigious honour. In 1999, he was awarded the Harold White Fellowship at the [[National Library of Australia]].{{cite web|url=http://sealang.net/archives/luce/UThawKaung.pdf|title=PAPERS OF GORDON LUCE |date=August 1999 |publisher=NATIONAL LIBRARY OF AUSTRALIA|accessdate=20 July 2015}} ==Awards== Thaw Kaung was conferred an [[Honorary Doctor of Letters]] by the [[University of Western Sydney]] in 1999.{{cite web|url=http://www.uws.edu.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0004/415552/Honorary_Awards_as_at_June_2015.pdf|title=UWS Honorary Awards (by name)|publisher=University of Western Sydney|accessdate=20 July 2015}} In 2005, he won the [[Fukuoka Asian Culture Prize]] in the Academic Prize category for his professional contributions. In 2008, he was awarded the [[Pakokku U Ohn Pe literary award|Pakokku U Ohn Pe lifetime achievement award]] for his contributions to Burmese literature. In 2010, he was awarded the [[Burma National Literature Award|Myanmar National Literature Award]] Lifetime Achievement in Literature the Burmese government. Various awards conferred in chronological order is as follows: (1) B.A. (Honours) First class in English Language and Literature (University of Rangoon, 1959). Winner of U Po Hnit Gold Medal. (2) Postgraduate Diploma in Librarianship (University College London, University of London). Specialization in Oriental Bibliography. (1962) (3) Honorary Fellow of the Library Association (U.K.) (Since 1984). Hon.F.L.A. awarded for achievements in librarianship, including the establishment of the first Library Studies Dept. at the University of Yangon (Rangoon). (4) Associate of the Australian Library and Information Association. (1976) (5) Certificate from Western Australian Institute of Technology, (now Curtin University), Perth, for Training in Library Studies, specializing in methods of teaching library studies. (1976) (6) Doctor of Letters (University of Western Sydney) Honoris Causa (1999) (7) Awarded by Fukuoka Asian Culture Prizes as Academic Prize Laureate in 2005. (8) Awarded “Sithu Award” by Myanmar Government ==Personal life== Thaw Kaung married Khin Than in 1964. They have 3 sons: Min Thaw Kaung, Thant Thaw Kaung, and Myat Thaw Kaung. He resides in [[Bahan Township]], [[Yangon]]. ==Publications== {{expand list|date=July 2015}} *''Selected Writings of U Thaw Kaung''{{cite web|url=http://www.culture.gov.mm/DHR_mm/Book_List_mm/default.asp?id=177|title=ထုတ်ဝေခဲ့သည့် စာအုပ်များ|date=2013|publisher=Ministry of Culture|accessdate=20 July 2015}} (2004) *''From the Librarian’s Window: Views of Library and Manuscript Studies and Myanmar Literature''{{cite news|url=http://www.mmtimes.com/index.php/lifestyle/2802-uphill-fight-to-preserve-palm-leaf-texts.html|title=Uphill fight to preserve palm leaf texts|last=Zon Pann Pwint|date=9 May 2011|work=Myanmar Times|accessdate=20 July 2015}} (2008) *''The Aspects of Myanmar History and Culture''{{cite news|url=http://www.mmtimes.com/index.php/lifestyle/5525-myanmar-history-book-published.html|title=Myanmar history book published|last=Zon Pann Pwint|date=15 March 2010|work=Myanmar Times|accessdate=20 July 2015}} (2010) Details of U Thaw Kaung's articles and publications are as follows: (1) Library Manual (the first handbook in Myanmar) Compiler and chapters on cataloguing. Two versions. Two editions. (2) On Reference Books (in Myanmar). (3) On Translations (also in Myanmar). (4) Several articles on books and librarianship in Myanmar and in English. (5) Have published several research papers in Myanmar Historical Research Journal; also Jt. Editor and Jt. Secretary to the Editorial Board. Have read papers at annual Conferencesa and published in Proceedings of Conferences, Universities Historical Research Centre, Yangon. (6) Have read and published some papers in Journal of the Siam Society; elected Honorary Corresponding Member of the Siam Society since 1993 to present. (7) Have submitted some of my papers for publication to the National University of Singapore. (8) Recent articles (i) “Preservation microfilming of Myanmar manuscripts” (ii) “Microfilming of the Myanmar newspaper Suriya (the Sun)” (iii) “Japanese microfilming team in Myanmar, 1973-1974” (all three articles in Southeast Asia Microfilms Newsletter, issue no. 21, 1991. Institute of Southeast Asian Studies, Singapore) (iv) “Myanmar National Library”, Kekal Abadi, jil 10, bil 2, June 1991, University of Malaya Library Journal, Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. (v) “Myanmar Traditional Manuscripts and their Preservation and Conservation”, Myanmar Historical Research Journal, no.1 (Nov. 1995)p. 241-273. (vi) “Sithu Gamani Thingyan and his Zinme Yazawin, the Myanmar Version of the Chiang Mai Chronicle” in Proceedings of the 6th International (vii) “On the Myanmar Ramayana and Thai Connections”. Paper read at Chulalongkorn University 1998. Two research papers. (viii) “On Myanmar Ceramics”. Paper read at International Conference in Singapore, 1998. (ix) “Post-colonial Society and Culture : reflections in Myanmar novels of the last 50 years”, (jt-author with U Than Htut). Proceedings of the Conference on Post Colonial Society and Culture in South East Asia. Yangon: UHRC, 1999. (x) “Bibliographies Compiled in Myanmar,” Etudes Birmanes en hommage a Denise Bernot. Paris: EFEO, 1998. (xi) “The Myanmar Library Association and Endeavours for its Formation”. Paper read at IFLA General Conference, August 1999, Bangkok. (xii) “Myanmar Biographical Writings in the 20th century”(jt-author with U Than Htut), Proceedings of the Views and Visions Conference. Yangon: UHRC, 2001. (xiii) “Some Myanmar Historical Fiction and their Historical Context”,(jt-author with U Than Htut). (xiv) Two research papers on King Bayinnaung (1551-1581)for Conferences with Chulalongkorn University, Bangkok-2001; Yangon-2003. (xv) “Ethnographical Studies on the Ethnic Groups of Myanmar,” Minpaku Anthropology Newsletter, Osaka, no.14 (June 2002). (xvi) About 50 articles on Places of Historical Interest in Myanmar, for Myanmar Perspectives monthly Internet magazine (1995 to date). In English language. Bibliographies and Indexes (1) Index to Periodical Articles in English on Burma, 1948 to 1962. (2) Bibliography of the Works of U Pe Maung Tin (Eminent Pali Scholar and former Chairman, Myanmar Historical Commission). Abstract published in Ngwe-tar-yi, a local Myanmar monthly magazine; later published in a monograph, 2001. (3) Bibliography of Works on Myanmar Literature. Compiled jointly with U Than Htut and Daw San San May (British Library) Published in Myanmar, Yangon: Sarpay Beikman (the Institute of Literature), 1983.392 items with index. (4) Bibliography of Myanmar Art and Archaeology. Compiled jointly with Dr. Elizabeth Moore (SOAS, Univ. of London) and Daw San San Maw (former Librarian, Archaeology Dept., Yangon). 1993. Unpublishe. Available on computer. (5) Bibliography of Early Printed Books in Myanmar, 1819-1885. Compiled in 1992. Available on computer. (6) Index to Papers of Gordon H. Luce. Compiled for the National Library of Australia, 1999. Available on the Internet. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.asianmonth.com/prize/english/lecture/pdf/16_02.pdf Thaw Kaung's keynote lecture at the 2005 Fukuoka Asian Culture Prize ceremony] *[http://203.131.219.245/conference2012/pdf/U%20Thaw%20Kaung%20CV.pdf Curriculum vitae] {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Thaw Kaung}} [[Category:Burmese people of Chinese descent]] [[Category:People from Yangon]] [[Category:Burmese academics]] [[Category:Burmese historians]] [[Category:University of Yangon alumni]] [[Category:1937 births]] [[Category:Living people]]
