Herbert Schandler|title=Argument Without End: In Search of Answers to the Vietnam Tragedy|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CH--mDP5sGoC&pg=PA328|date=2 November 2007|publisher=PublicAffairs|isbn=1-58648-621-7|pages=328–}}</ref> * November 22: US President John Fitzgerald Kennedy is assassinated in Dallas, TX at age 46. Vice President Lyndon B. Johnson is sworn in as 36th President of the US.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Lane|first1=Mark|title=Rush to Judgment|date=1966|publisher=Thunder's Mouth Press|location=New York|isbn=1-56025-043-7|page=7|edition=Paperback, 1992}}</ref> * November 24: Suspected JFK assassin [[Lee Harvey Oswald]] is himself murdered by [[Jack Ruby]] under lax police security in Dallas, thereby creating doubt for many, and opening the door to myriad [[Kennedy assassination conspiracy theories|conspiracy theories]] concerning the [[Kennedy Assassination]] and the veracity of later [[Warren Report|government findings]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Marrs|first1=Jim|title=Crossfire: The Plot That Killed Kennedy|date=1989|publisher=Carroll & Graf|location=New York|isbn=0-88184-648-1|edition=1st Paperback, 1990|chapter=Preface}}</ref>
===1964=== * January: [[The Holy Modal Rounders]]' version of "Hesitation Blues" marks the first reference to the term ''psychedelic'' in popular music.<ref name="Leech2010">{{cite book|author=Jeanette Leech|title=Seasons They Change: The Story of Acid and Psychedelic Folk|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EoAmZf_RPGoC&pg=PA37|year=2010|publisher=Jawbone Press|isbn=978-1-906002-32-9|pages=37–}}</ref> * January 8: LBJ's State of the Union address features a declaration of "[[War on Poverty]]".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Johnson|first1=Lyndon Baines|title=Annual Message to the Congress on the State of the Union. January 8, 1964|url=http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/ws/?pid=26787|website=.presidency.ucsb.edu|publisher=Gerhard Peters and John T. Woolley – The American Presidency Project via UCSB|accessdate=February 12, 2015|quote=Let this session of Congress be known as the session which did more for civil rights than the last hundred sessions combined; as the session which enacted the most far-reaching tax cut of our time; as the session which declared all-out war on human poverty and unemployment in these United States; as the session which finally recognized the health needs of all our older citizens; as the session which reformed our tangled transportation and transit policies; as the session which achieved the most effective, efficient foreign aid program ever; and as the session which helped to build more homes, more schools, more libraries, and more hospitals than any single session of Congress in the history of our Republic.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=For LBJ, The War On Poverty Was Personal|url=https://www.npr.org/2014/01/08/260572389/for-lbj-the-war-on-poverty-was-personal|website=npr.org|publisher=NPR|accessdate=February 12, 2015|date=January 8, 2014|quote=President Lyndon Johnson stood in the Capitol on Jan. 8, 1964, and, in his first State of the Union address, committed the nation to a war on poverty. "We shall not rest until that war is won," Johnson said. "The richest nation on Earth can afford to win it. We cannot afford to lose it." It was an effort that had been explored under President Kennedy, but it firmly — and quickly — took shape under Johnson.}}</ref> * January 13: ''[[The Times They Are a-Changin' (album)|The Times They Are A-Changin']]'': Bob Dylan's 3rd album is released and the [[The Times They Are A-Changin' (song)|title track]] is soon considered to be the most prophetic and relevant American [[protest song]] of the era. Dylan disagrees, saying the song "is a feeling."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Sanburn|first1=Josh|title=The 10 Best Bob Dylan Songs: 'The Times They Are A-Changin'|url=http://entertainment.time.com/2011/05/23/the-10-best-bob-dylan-songs/slide/the-times-they-are-a-changin/|accessdate=2015-11-07|publisher=Time, Inc.|date=2011-05-09}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=500 Greatest Songs of All Time: 59 Bob Dylan, 'The Times They Are A-Changin'|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/the-500-greatest-songs-of-all-time-20110407/bob-dylan-the-times-they-are-a-changin-20110525|accessdate=2015-11-07|publisher=Rolling Stone}}</ref> * January 23: [[24th Amendment]] ratified: US Congress and states are prohibited from conditioning the right to vote in federal elections on payment of poll or other forms of tax.<ref>{{cite web|title=Historical Highlights: The 24th Amendment|url=http://history.house.gov/HistoricalHighlight/Detail/37045|website=history.house.gov|publisher=U.S. House of Representatives (History, Art & Archives)|accessdate=March 1, 2015|quote=On this date in 1962, the House passed the 24th Amendment, outlawing the poll tax as a voting requirement in federal elections, by a vote of 295 to 86. At the time, five states maintained poll taxes which disproportionately affected African-American voters: Virginia, Alabama, Mississippi, Arkansas, and Texas. The poll tax exemplified "Jim Crow" laws, developed in the post-Reconstruction South, which aimed to disenfranchise black voters and institute segregation.}}</ref> * February 1: [[I Want to Hold Your Hand]]: The Beatles achieve their first hit #1 on ''Billboard'' with a 7-week run on top. [[The Beatles in the United States|Beatlemania]] has spread to the US, and the monumental [[British Invasion]] of UK music across the free world is underway.<ref>{{cite web|title=Beatlemania Comes to the United States|url=http://rockhall.com/blog/post/today-in-rock-beatles-arrive-in-new-york/|website=rockhall.com|publisher=Rock & Roll Hall of Fame|accessdate=March 1, 2015|date=February 3, 2015|quote=In Britain, "I Want to Hold Your Hand" saw its official release on December 5, 1963, reaching Number One the following week. It held the position for five weeks. Soon thereafter, American DJs began spinning the import single and the immediate, positive response prompted Capitol to not only bump up the release date to December 26, but also increase the press run from 200,000 copies to one million. A media blitz followed, as reporters from the Associated Press, CBS, Life, New York Times and more were assigned to cover the Beatles. "I Want to Hold Your Hand" reached Number One on the Billboard charts on February 1, 1964, and remained on the Billboard Hot 100 for seven weeks.}}</ref><ref name="Miles2009">{{cite book|author=Barry Miles|title=The British Invasion|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=r8xbaIlrUREC|year=2009|publisher=Sterling Publishing Company, Inc.|isbn=978-1-4027-6976-4}}</ref> * February 3: Nearly half a million public school students in NYC boycott classes in protest of segregation.<ref>{{cite web|title=New York School Boycott|url=http://crdl.usg.edu/events/ny_school_boycott/|website=crdl.usg.org|publisher=Civil Rights Digital Library/Digital Library of Georgia|accessdate=2017-03-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Khan|first1=Yasmeen|title=Demand for School Integration Leads to Massive 1964 Boycott — In New York City|url=http://www.wnyc.org/story/school-boycott-1964/|website=wnyc.org|accessdate=2017-03-17|date=2016-02-03|quote=After hearing too many "vague promises" from the New York City Board of Education to integrate the schools, civil rights activists in 1964 called for swift action: desegregate the city's schools and improve the inferior conditions of many that enrolled black and Latino students. To force the issue, they staged a one-day school boycott on Feb. 3, when approximately 460,000 students refused to go to school.}}</ref> * February 7–22: The Beatles make their first US visit and are showcased three times on ''[[The Ed Sullivan Show]]''. The February 9 telecast is seen by over 73 million, the largest TV audience to date in the US.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.edsullivan.com/artists/the-beatles |title=The Beatles |date=2010 |website=edsullivan.com |publisher=SOFA Entertainment |accessdate=June 10, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Harding|first1=Barrie|title=5,000 scream 'welcome' to the Beatles|url=http://www.bl.uk/learning/timeline/large126878.html|accessdate=2015-12-24|issue=No. 18,704|publisher=Daily Mirror|date=1964-02-08}}</ref> * February 25–26: Tens of thousands of school students in Boston and Chicago skip classes in protest of segregation. * April 4: Beatles singles occupy the top 5 slots on the Billboard Hot 100. It's an unprecedented, and never repeated, chart achievement.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Trust|first1=Gary|title=April 4, 1964: The Beatles Control Entire Top Five On Billboard Hot 100|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/1555851/april-4-1964-the-beatles-control-entire-top-five-on-billboard|website=billboard.com|publisher=Billboard|accessdate=2016-08-11|date=2013-04-04|quote=On the Billboard Hot 100 dated April 4, 1964, 49 years ago today, the Beatles made history as the only act ever to occupy the chart's top five positions in a week. With a 27–1 second-week blast to the top for "Can't Buy Me Love," the Fab Four locked up the chart's entire top five: No. 1, "Can't Buy Me Love" No. 2, "Twist and Shout" No. 3, "She Loves You" No. 4, "I Want to Hold Your Hand" No. 5, "Please Please Me"}}</ref><ref>Bronson, p. 145.</ref> *April 13: [[Sidney Portier]] becomes the first man of African descent to win the Oscar for Best Actor, Santa Monica, CA.<ref name="Times2014">{{cite book|author=The New York Times|title=New York Times The Times of the Sixties: The Culture, Politics, and Personalities that Shaped the Decade|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6VQlAgAAQBAJ&pg=PT1136|date=10 June 2014|publisher=Running Press|isbn=978-1-60376-366-0|pages=1136–}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=France |first1=Lisa Respers |title=All the best actor Oscar winners through the years |url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/03/01/entertainment/oscars-best-actor-winners/index.html |website=cnn.com |publisher=CNN |accessdate=2018-06-03 |date=2018-03-01}}</ref> * April 20: Approximately 85% of black students in Cleveland boycott classes to protest segregation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2013/02/the_1964_cleveland_schools_boy.html|title=The 1964 Cleveland schools' boycott to protest segregation: Black History Month|publisher=}}</ref> * May: [[Robert Jasper Grootveld]]'s surreal [[happenings]] begin in [[Spui (Amsterdam)|Spui]] square [[Amsterdam]] with his unpredictable performances and famous cries of "Klaas is Coming!" and "Uche, Uche, Uche". Later described as the "announcer of the international spirit of revolution" he gained a following of [[Nozem]]s (Dutch rockers) and inspired the start of the [[Provo (movement)|Provo (Provocation)]] movement in both Holland and California, introducing a playful element into social protest.<ref>{{cite web | quote = '''No single person can be said to have created the worldwide cultural phenomenon we call "the Sixties".''' But the Dutch anti-smoking "magician" and voodoo showman '''Robert Jasper Grootveld has a better claim than most.''' In the early Sixties, his surreal, dadaist "happenings" in Amsterdam electrified the city's bored youth and led to the creation of the playful Provo movement (short for "provocation"). With the charismatic, flamboyantly transvestite Grootveld as a spokesman, Provo was a catalyst for cultural revolution. The group provided free bicycles, subverted a royal wedding and humiliated the stiff-necked Dutch establishment and Amsterdam police force so effectively that both groups – and the country – underwent a near-total personality change. Provo lasted only from 1965 to 1967 but the spirit of what Grootveld dubbed "International Magic Centre Amsterdam" broke old Holland, inspired hippies in San Francisco and musicians and artists in London and paved the way, among other things, for the summer of love, Dutch total football and the green movement. | url = https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/robert-jasper-grootveld-artist-and-activist-who-helped-found-the-dutch-provos-in-the-1960s-1687682.html | title = Robert Jasper Grootveld: Artist and activist who helped found the Dutch Provos in the 1960s | last = Winner | first = David | date = 19 May 2009 | website = www.independent.co.uk | publisher = The Independent | access-date = 3 December 2016 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.iisg.nl/grootveld/documents/hipperzweters-voorjaar-1964.pdf International Institute of Social History – Grootveld flyers]</ref> * May: Appearance of the ''Faire Free Press'' (later the ''[[Los Angeles Free Press]]''), earliest of many "underground" US newspapers of the counterculture era. * May: San Francisco [[1960s Berkeley protests#Sheraton Palace Demonstration|Sheraton Palace Hotel]] sit-ins result in arrests of University of California, Berkeley students protesting racially discriminatory Bay area hiring practices.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://content.cdlib.org/view?docId=kt896nb2pw&doc.view=frames&chunk.id=div00002&toc.id=0 |title=Photographs:Sheraton Palace Demonstration, May 1964 |last1=Enfield |first1=Robert | website=cdlib.org |publisher=University of California |accessdate=May 7, 2014}}</ref> * May 7: President Johnson first refers to "the [[Great Society]]" in a speech at [[Ohio University]], Athens, OH. * May 12: The first public [[draft-card burning]] is reported in New York City.<ref name="Farrell1997">{{cite book|author=James J. Farrell|title=The Spirit of the Sixties: Making Postwar Radicalism|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Gkot_syANs0C&pg=PA180|date=January 1997|publisher=Psychology Press|isbn=978-0-415-91385-0|pages=180–}}</ref> * June 14: [[Merry Pranksters|The Merry Pranksters]]: Led by author [[Ken Kesey]], an assemblage of adventure seekers departs California in the repurposed school bus ''[[Further (bus)|Further]]'' en route to the [[1964 New York World's Fair|1964 World's Fair]] in Queens, NY.<ref name="Hales2014">{{cite book|author=Peter Bacon Hales|title=Outside the Gates of Eden: The Dream of America from Hiroshima to Now|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NohFAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA317|date=11 April 2014|publisher=University of Chicago Press|isbn=978-0-226-12861-0|pages=317–}}</ref> * June 22: [[Jacobellis v. Ohio|I Know it When I See it]]: The US Supreme Court overturns the obscenity conviction of an Ohio theater operator. Although local obscenity battles continue to the present, the decision clears the way for the commercial exhibition of [[pornography|sexually explicit]] film material in the US.<ref name="GreenKarolides2009">{{cite book|author1=Green|author2=Nicholas J. Karolides|title=Encyclopedia of Censorship|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bunHURgi7FcC&pg=PA301|date=January 1, 2009|publisher=Infobase Publishing|isbn=978-1-4381-1001-1|pages=301–}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Jacobellis v. Ohio - 378 U.S. 184 (1964)|url=http://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/378/184/case.html|website=supreme.justia.com|publisher=justia.com|accessdate=July 9, 2014}}</ref> * July 2: The [[Civil Rights Act of 1964|Civil Rights Act]] is signed by President Johnson. While this was not technically The Moptops first-time toking — they shared a joint in Hamburg but couldn't agree whether or not they got high — they definitely copped a buzz with Dylan in New York.}}</ref> * October 1: The [[Free Speech Movement]] begins with a student sit-in at the University of California, Berkeley.<ref>{{cite web|title=Visual History: Free Speech Movement, 1964-Mario Savio addresses the crowd|url=http://fsm.berkeley.edu/free-speech-movement-timeline/|accessdate=March 1, 2015|quote=Mario Savio addresses the crowd Mario Savio climbs on top of the police car containing Jack Weinberg to address the crowd of demonstrators. He is the first to make the message of brotherly love a reality in the course of his struggle, and he has brought this message to all men, to all nations and races. Today we pay tribute to Martin Luther King, the man who has never abandoned his faith in the unarmed struggle he is waging, who has suffered for his faith, who has been imprisoned on many occasions, whose home has been subject to bomb attacks, whose life and the lives of his family have been threatened, and who nevertheless has never faltered.}}</ref> * October 25: Bad boys [[The Rolling Stones]] appear on Ed Sullivan and create so much audience disruption that Sullivan bans the "lewd" group from his show. Rorabaugh Professor of History University of Washington|title=Berkeley at War : The 1960s: The 1960s|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WW2jpQ36kSAC&pg=PA134|date=May 4, 1989|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-802252-7|pages=134–}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://content.cdlib.org/view?docId=kt896nb2pw;NAAN=13030&doc.view=frames&chunk.id=div00008&toc.depth=1&toc.id=&brand=calisphere |title=Photographs:Filthy Speech Rally, Spring, 1965 |last1=Enfield |first1=Robert | website=cdlib.org |publisher=University of California |accessdate=May 7, 2014}}</ref> * March 6: Regular US troops engage in combat in Vietnam for the first time. * March 7–25: The SCLC stages the watershed [[Selma to Montgomery marches]], initially organized by James Bevel. * March 16: [[Alice Herz]], age 82, self-immolates in Detroit, MI in protest of Vietnam escalation. The working vacation, financed on Phillips' American Express card, results in the formation of the [[Mamas and the Papas]], and a lucrative recording contract. The events are recounted in song on the group's hit 1967 single "[[Creeque Alley]]".<ref name="Greenwald2002">{{cite book|author=Matthew Greenwald|title=Go Where You Wanna Go: The Oral History of The Mamas and The Papas|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sQk3qbUp1E8C&pg=PA212|date=30 April 2002|publisher=Cooper Square Press|isbn=978-1-4616-2290-1|pages=212–}}</ref> * April: Beatles [[John Lennon]] and [[George Harrison]] experience LSD for the first time at a UK dinner party hosted by Harrison's dentist.<ref name="Roberts2008">{{cite book|author=Andy Roberts|title=Albion Dreaming: A popular history of LSD in Britain (Revised Edition with a new foreword by Sue Blackmore)|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2caIAAAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false|date=September 30, 2008|publisher=Marshall Cavendish International Asia Pte Ltd|isbn=978-981-4328-97-5}}</ref>{{rp|98}}<ref>{{cite news|last1=Herbert|first1=Ian|title=Revealed: Dentist who introduced Beatles to LSD|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/news/revealed-dentist-who-introduced-beatles-to-lsd-6231654.html|accessdate=2016-01-07|publisher=The Independent|date=2006-09-08}}</ref> * April: US combat troops in Vietnam total 25,000. * April 16: [[Bert Jansch (album)|Needle of Death]]: The debut album of Scottish folk musician [[Bert Jansch]] features a song of warning concerning the deadly dangers of heroin.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Cromelin |first1=Richard |title=Bert Jansch dies at 67; Hundreds march to the draft board, where Lyndon Johnson is hanged in effigy, and many burn draft cards.<ref name =UCBL65 /><ref>{{cite web |url=http://museumca.org/picturethis/timeline/unforgettable-change-1960s/1960s-vietnam-and-berkeley/info |title=Unforgettable Change: 1960s: 1960s in Vietnam and in Berkeley (Text and Audio Content)|website=museumca.org |publisher=Oakland Museum of California |accessdate=June 20, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://content.cdlib.org/view?docId=kt896nb2pw;NAAN=13030&doc.view=frames&chunk.id=div00009&toc.depth=1&toc.id=&brand=calisphere |title=Photographs:Vietnam Day, Spring, 1965 |last1=Enfield |first1=Robert | website=cdlib.org |publisher=University of California |accessdate=May 7, 2014}}</ref> * May: [[Drop City]]: One of the earliest hippie [[commune]]s is founded in Colorado, US. The Droppers build [[geodesic domes]] from trashed automobile hoods and roofs, notably involving collaborations with [[Steve Baer]] and [[Buckminster Fuller]] inspired [[Zome]]s.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Knopper|first1=Steve|title=Colorado's Famous Historic Artist Commune|url=http://www.5280.com/news/magazine/2015/08/colorados-famous-historic-artist-commune|website=5280.com|publisher=5280 The Denver Magazine|accessdate=2015-12-30|date=2015-09-01|quote=At the time, the idea of a commune—a place where young artists would live off sales of their work and share a bank account to buy food and supplies—was new and exciting. The concept attracted those who identified with the blossoming '60s counterculture. Prominent figures in the movement, including eventual Woodstock Nation members such as LSD guru Timothy Leary and the Doors' Jim Morrison, ventured to this plot of land in Trinidad. What they found when they arrived was a utopia born from the zeitgeist of 1960s America—a place unlike anywhere else in Colorado.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://brbl-archive.library.yale.edu/exhibitions/utopia/uc19.html|title=America and the Utopian Dream – Utopian Communities|website=brbl-archive.library.yale.edu}}</ref> * June–August: [[Red Dog Experience]] comes into full flower at [[Virginia City, Nevada]]'s Red Dog Saloon – full-fledged "hippie" identity takes shape. * June 7: ''[[Griswold v. "[[Comstock law|Comstock-era]]" laws are likewise now moot in other states. In 1972, the court rules that protections apply to unmarried couples as well.<ref name="Hudson2007">{{cite book|author=William E. Hudson|title=The Libertarian Illusion: Ideology, Public Policy and the Assault on the Common Good|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WgemAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA191|date=December 28, 2007|publisher=SAGE Publications|isbn=978-1-4833-0122-8|pages=191–}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Margaret Sanger (1879–1966)|url=http://ocp.hul.harvard.edu/ww/sanger.html|website=ocp.hul.harvard.edu|publisher=Harvard University Library|accessdate=August 13, 2014|quote=In 1965, the Supreme Court decision in Griswold v. Connecticut legalized contraception for married couples.}}</ref><ref>{{cite episode | title = The Times they are a Changin'| | series = The Sixties (Documentary Series) | credits = CNN | network = CNN | airdate = August 7, 2014 }}</ref> *June 11: [[International Poetry Incarnation]]: Notables including Allen Ginsberg, [[Lawrence Ferlinghetti]], [[Michael Horovitz]], and [[William S. The myth that the group smoked marijuana in a palace bathroom after the investiture ceremony in October is later debunked by George Harrison.<ref name="GraffDurchholz2012">{{cite book|author1=Gary Graff|author2=Daniel Durchholz|title=Rock 'n' Roll Myths: The True Stories Behind the Most Infamous Legends|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=g3SaB1-cr74C&pg=PT118|date=12 June 2012|publisher=Voyageur Press|isbn=978-0-7603-4230-5|pages=118–}}</ref> * July 25: Bob Dylan [[Dylan goes electric|"goes electric"]] and is booed by some at the Newport Folk Festival.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Righthand|first1=Jess|title=July 25, 1965: Dylan Goes Electric at the Newport Folk Festival|url=http://www.smithsonianmag.com/smithsonian-institution/july-25-1965-dylan-goes-electric-at-the-newport-folk-festival-114743/?no-ist|website=smithsonian.com|accessdate=2015-02-14|date=2010-07-23|quote=It was during that concert, 45 years ago today, that Bob Dylan plugged in his electric guitar, an action that would alter the landscape of American popular music for generations to come. On that day, as boos, shouts and cries for "the old Dylan" rose above the music, Dylan departed from his acoustic roots and ventured into the realm of rock 'n' roll, a genre generally disdained as commercial and mainstream by Dylan's bohemian peers of the 1960s American folk music revival. In doing this, the artist forged the way for the folk-rock genre, merging his lyrical songwriting style with the hard-driving sounds of rock.}}</ref> * July 30: [[Medicare (United States)|Medicare]] is signed into law in the US, giving seniors a healthcare safety net. * August: Phil Ochs releases the satirical "[[Draft Dodger Rag]]" on the album ''[[I Ain't Marching Anymore]]''. He later performs the song on the CBS News Special ''Avoiding the Draft''. Pete Seeger's version appears in 1966.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://rateyourmusic.com/release/album/phil-ochs/i-aint-marching-anymore/|title=I Ain't Marching Anymore by Phil Ochs|publisher=}}</ref> * August 6: The [[Voting Rights Act]] is signed into law in the US; "[[Literacy tests]]", [[Poll tax (United States)|poll taxes]] and other local schemes to prevent voting by blacks are newly or further banned under federal law. * August 11: [[1965 Watts Riot|Watts]]: Six days of massive race riots erupt in Los Angeles: 34 dead, 1000 injuries, 100s of buildings looted or destroyed, and thousands of arrests. Meanwhile, smaller riots occur in Chicago.<ref>{{cite web|title=Watts Riots|url=http://crdl.usg.edu/events/watts_riots/?Welcome|website=crdl.usg.edu|publisher=Civil Rights Digital Library/Digital Library of Georgia|accessdate=2018-04-28|quote=The Watts Riot, which raged for six days and resulted in more than forty million dollars worth of property damage, was both the largest and costliest urban rebellion of the Civil Rights era. The riot spurred from an incident on August 11, 1965 when Marquette Frye, a young African American motorist, was pulled over and arrested by Lee W. Minikus, a white California Highway Patrolman, for suspicion of driving while intoxicated. As a crowd on onlookers gathered at the scene of Frye's arrest, strained tensions between police officers and the crowd erupted in a violent exchange. The outbreak of violence that followed Frye's arrest immediately touched off a large-scale riot centered in the commercial section of Watts, a deeply impoverished African American neighborhood in South Central Los Angeles. For several days, rioters overturned and burned automobiles and looted and damaged grocery stores, liquor stores, department stores, and pawnshops. Over the course of the six-day riot, over 14,000 California National Guard troops were mobilized in South Los Angeles and a curfew zone encompassing over forty-five miles was established in an attempt to restore public order. All told, the rioting claimed the lives of thirty-four people, resulted in more than one thousand reported injuries, and almost four thousand arrests before order was restored on August 17. Throughout the crisis, public officials advanced the argument that the riot was the work outside agitators; however, an official investigation, prompted by Governor Pat Brown, found that the riot was a result of the Watts community's longstanding grievances and growing discontentment with high unemployment rates, substandard housing, and inadequate schools. Despite the reported findings of the gubernatorial commission, following the riot, city leaders and state officials failed to implement measures to improve the social and economic conditions of African Americans living in the Watts neighborhood.}}</ref> * August 24: [[She Said She Said]]: Shortly after setting a concert attendance record at [[The Beatles at Shea Stadium|Shea Stadium]], Queens, NY, the Beatles briefly rest in [[Benedict Canyon]], near the end of their grueling [[The Beatles' 1965 US tour|American tour]]. With ongoing Beatlemania preventing the band from leaving their rented home, they invite local company, including members of the [[The Byrds|Byrds]], [[Peter Fonda]], Joan Baez, and [[Peggy Lipton]]. Lennon writes a song, which appears on ''[[Revolver (Beatles album)|Revolver]]'' in 1966. As the era progresses, nearby [[Laurel Canyon]] becomes home to many prominent counterculture musicians.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Miles|first1=Barry|title=The Beatles: A Diary|date=1998|publisher=Omnibus Press|isbn=978-0-7119-9196-5}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Montagne|first1=Renee|title=Music and Mayhem in 'Laurel Canyon'|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=5778064|accessdate=2015-11-25|publisher=NPR|date=2012-12-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Robinson|first1=Lisa|title=An Oral History of Laurel Canyon, the 60s and 70s Music Mecca|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/culture/2015/02/laurel-canyon-music-scene|accessdate=2015-11-25|publisher=Vanity Fair/Conde Nast|date=2015-02-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Reed|first1=Ryan|title=Paul on Drums, George on Bass: 10 Great Beatles Instrument Swaps|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/paul-on-drums-george-on-bass-10-great-beatles-instrument-swaps-20150915/she-said-she-said-20150911|website=rollingstone.com|publisher=Rolling Stone|accessdate=2018-05-19|date=2015-09-15|quote=McCartney's melodic bass work is a signature of the Beatles' oeuvre, but Harrison did a great job approximating it on the psychedelic Revolver meditation "She Said She Said" — one of the band's only tracks not to feature Sir Paul. "I think we'd had a barney or something, and I said, 'Oh, fuck you!' and they said, 'Well, we'll do it,'" McCartney told Barry Miles in the 1998 biography Many Years From Now. The song was inspired by Lennon's 1965 LSD trip with Byrds members Roger McGuinn and David Crosby, during which actor Peter Fonda told a frightened Harrison that he knew "what it's like to be dead." ===1967=== * January 1: The US [[Federal Communications Commission]] (FCC) implements radio non-duplication rules: [[FM Radio|FM]] stations must broadcast at least 50% original content, and not simply simulcasts of their [[Am radio|AM]] sister stations. Soon, FM DJs have the avenue to play the music of the generation without regard to AM chart status.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Comoratta|first1=Len|title=Rock History 101: Freeform Radio|url=http://consequenceofsound.net/2011/05/rock-history-101-freeform-radio/|publisher=Consequence of Sound • A Member of Townsquare Music|accessdate=March 1, 2015|date=May 15, 2011|quote=In the early days of FM, broadcasts were principally educational programming and classical music aimed at a more "upmarket listenership." AM stations simply duplicated their programming onto the FM band, widening their audience with little effort. In 1965, the Federal Communications Commission enacted the FM Non-Duplication Rule. Until this law, AM stations were allowed to rebroadcast the majority of their programming on their FM stations. However, with the passage of the FM Non-Duplication Rule, as of January 1, 1967, FM stations would have to broadcast original content over 50% of their broadcast day. Station programmers and owners now faced with having to create original content were forced to exit the box that was the Top 40 format and begin experimenting.}}</ref><ref name="Cox2013">{{cite book|author=Jim Cox|title=Radio After the Golden Age: The Evolution of American Broadcasting Since 1960|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PXOvAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA59|date=16 September Seale and five others are arrested.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Winkler|first1=Adam|title=The Secret History of Guns|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2011/09/the-secret-history-of-guns/308608/|website=theatlantic.com|publisher=The Atlantic Monthly Group|accessdate=October 10, 2014|date=July 24, 2011|quote=It was May 2, 1967, and the Black Panthers' invasion of the California statehouse launched the modern gun-rights movement.}}</ref> * May 5: [[Mr. Natural (comics)|Mr. Natural]]: [[Robert Crumb|Robert Crumb's]] soon to be ubiquitous underground comix counterculture icon, makes his first appearance in the premiere issue of ''[[Yarrowstalks]].''<ref>{{cite web|title=Yarrowstalks Archives|url=http://library.temple.edu/scrc/yarrowstalks-archives|website=library.temple.edu|publisher=Temple University|accessdate=October 14, 2014|date=1977|quote=Twelve issues of ''Yarrowstalks'' were published in Philadelphia from 1967 until 1975. Most of the activity was concentrated at the beginning of the period, in the heyday of underground press activity. The "summer of love" in 1967 saw the birth of about 100 underground publications nationwide, and Yarrowstalks was one of the first. It was the most physically appealing of the first wave in its creative use of color and artwork. In contrast to the other Philadelphia papers, ''Yarrowstalks'' leaned away from the politics. Like New York's East Village Other and the ''San Francisco Oracle'', ''Yarrowstalks'' was among the first underground paper to explore the graphic possibilities of cold-type offset printing. Color was splashed over pages with sketches and text. The ''Oracle'', particularly, was responsible for making newspaper graphics an art form, and it published some of the most beautiful and trend-setting psychedelic art of the 1960s. ''Yarrowstalks'' was Philadelphia's ''Oracle'', and it was the first of the undergrounds to publish the cartoons of Robert Crumb, an ex-Hallmark illustrator who has become the leading artist of underground "commix." In his character, Mr. Natural, he captured the feeling of the movement. Mr. Natural graced ''Yarrowstalks'' that summer and subsequently appeared in most of the alternative publications in the country.}}</ref> * May 10: Rolling Stone [[Brian Jones]] is arrested for drug possession. Jones' conviction record leaves him largely unable to tour outside of the UK.<ref name="Hitchens2013">{{cite book|author=Peter Hitchens|title=The War We Never Fought: The British Establishment's Surrender to Drugs|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cQZMAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA107|date=January 3, 2013|publisher=A&C Black|isbn=978-1-4411-7331-7|pages=107–}}</ref> * May 15–17: Student protesters confront police at [[Texas Southern University]], resulting in the death of a police officer, and over 400 arrests.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Bryson|first1=William|title=Texas Southern University: Born in Sin, A College Finally Makes Houston Listen|url=http://www.thecrimson.com/article/1967/5/22/texas-southern-university-born-in-sin/?page=single|website=thecrimson.com|publisher=The Harvard Crimson, Inc.|accessdate=October 15, 2014|date=May 22, 1967|quote=Since this article was written, the situation at Texas Southern has become even worse. A policeman was killed in rioting last week, and 488 people were arrested.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Zoch|first1=Louis|title=Fallen Officers Remembered: Louis Kuba|url=http://www.hpou.org/badgeandgun/index.cfm?fuseaction=view_news&NewsID=739|archive-url=https://archive.is/20141015171044/http://www.hpou.org/badgeandgun/index.cfm?fuseaction=view_news&NewsID=739|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2014-10-15|website=hpou.org|publisher=Houston Police Officers' Union|accessdate=January 14, 2015|date=May 2010|quote=At 2:20 a.m., a group of officers were near the northwest corner of the University Center, lined up along a wall awaiting directions from supervisors at the scene. Chief Short, like all of the other officers, took cover wherever possible. The chief directed officers to fire only when fired upon and only above the building or directly at a known source of the gunfire. Reporters Charley Schneider of The Houston Post and Nick Gearhardt of KHOU-TV (Channel 11), were with this group of officers. Schneider said that there were two officers and a TV newsman in front of him. He said that Officer Louis Kuba was directly behind him with his hand on Schneider's shoulder. Heavy fire continued from the dorm and Schneider suddenly felt Kuba's hand become limp. Turning, he saw the officer slumping backward into Gearhardt's outstretched arms, an expressionless look on his face and blood pouring from his forehead. Schneider reported in a Post article the following day, "There was no riot at TSU. It was war." An ambulance rushed the wounded officer to Ben Taub General Hospital. In the end, the draftees went into the center and the war machine continued.}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=1967: Joan Baez arrested in Vietnam protest|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/october/16/newsid_2535000/2535301.stm|website=news.bbc.co.uk|publisher=BBC|accessdate=October 18, 2014|quote=Rallies across America have taken place in 30 US cities, from Boston to Atlanta, to protest against the continuing war in Vietnam. In Oakland, California, at least 40 anti-war protesters, including the folk singer Joan Baez, were arrested for taking part in a sit-in at a military induction centre. As many as 250 demonstrators had gathered to try and prevent conscripts from entering the building when the arrests were made. The 'Stop the Draft Week' protests are forming part of a nationwide initiative organised by a group calling itself 'the Resistance'. Accompanied by singing from Baez and others, the sitting protesters forced draftees to climb over them in order to get inside the building. As they entered they were handed leaflets asking them to change their minds, refuse induction and join the protests. Human barricade Police formed a human barricade to enable inductees to pass and then made their arrests. In New York, around 500 demonstrators marched to protest against the draft. Young men placed draft cards into boxes marked 'Resisters'. 181 draft cards and several hundred protest cards were presented to a US Marshal but he refused to accept them. The group then marched to a post office and posted them directly to the Attorney General in Washington. The anti-war movement took on an added gravity yesterday when Florence Beaumont, mother of two, burned herself to death. After soaking herself in petrol she set herself alight in front of the Federal Building, Los Angeles. Counter-demonstrations have been planned by the National Committee for Responsible Patriotism, based in New York. Parades have been scheduled for the weekend in support of "our boys in Vietnam".|date=October 16, 1967}}</ref> * October 17: ''[[Hair (musical)|Hair]]'': a timely stageplay featuring controversial full frontal nudity premieres to mature audiences off-Broadway in New York City. The play becomes a Broadway smash in 1968.<ref name="Rockwell2014">{{cite book|author=John Rockwell|title=The New York Times the Times of the Sixties: The Culture, Politics, and Personalities That Shaped the Decade|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=X3GLAwAAQBAJ&pg=RA1-PA1940|date=3 June 2014|publisher=Hachette Books|isbn=978-1-57912-964-4|pages=1–}}</ref> * October 19: Thousands of students clash with police at [[Brooklyn College]] in New York after two military recruiters appear on campus. Students strike the following day.<ref>{{cite news|title=N.Y. Police, Students Battle|url=http://archives.chicagotribune.com/1967/10/20/page/2/article/n-y-police-students-battle|accessdate=2016-04-04|agency=UPI (1967-10-19) via Chicago Tribune (1967-10-20)|publisher=Chicago Tribune|date=1967-10-20}}</ref> * October 20–21: [[National Mobilization Committee to End the War in Vietnam|"Mobe's" March on the Pentagon]]: 100,000 protest the war in Washington, DC. Jerry Rubin, Abbie Hoffman and others lead attempts at "exorcism" and levitation of the [[Pentagon (building)|Pentagon]].<ref name="Elkholy2012">{{cite book|author=Sharin N. Elkholy|title=The Philosophy of the Beats|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=y6nsEu2JGvoC&pg=PA239|date=March 22, 2012|publisher=University Press of Kentucky|isbn=0-8131-4058-7|pages=239–}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Leen|first1=Jeff|title=The Vietnam Protests: When Worlds Collided|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/local/2000/vietnam092799.htm|website=washingtonpost.com|publisher=The Washington Post|accessdate=August 11, 2014|date=September 27, 1999|quote=The Pentagon march was the culmination of five days of nationwide anti-draft protests organized by the National Mobilization Committee to End the War in Vietnam – "the Mobe." But a singular spark was provided by the Youth International Party (Yippies), a fringe group whose leaders, Abbie Hoffman and Jerry Rubin, had announced that they planned an "exorcism" of the Pentagon. They would encircle the building, chant incantations, "levitate" the structure and drive out the evil war spirits.}}</ref> * October 27: Baltimore Four: Catholic priest [[Philip Berrigan]] and three others are jailed after pouring blood on draft files in the [[Selective Service System|SSS]] office, protesting bloodshed in Vietnam. Berrigan is later convicted.<ref name="Chepesiuk1995">{{cite book|author=Ron Chepesiuk|title=Sixties Radicals, Then and Now: Candid Conversations with Those Who Shaped the Era|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Pcb96S2WzfEC&pg=PA303|date=January 1, 1995|publisher=McFarland|isbn=978-0-7864-3732-0|pages=303–}}</ref> * October 28: Black Panther leader [[Huey Newton#Fatal shooting of John Frey|Huey Newton]] is stopped by Oakland police. A shootout resulting in the death of an officer leads to Newton's conviction, which is later overturned.<ref>{{cite web|title=Huey P. Newton Biography: Civil Rights Activist (1942–1989)|url=http://www.biography.com/people/huey-p-newton-37369#synopsis|website=biography.com|publisher=A&E Television Networks, LLC.|accessdate=August 11, 2014|quote=Newton himself was arrested in 1967 for allegedly killing an Oakland police officer during a traffic stop. He was later convicted of voluntary manslaughter and sentenced to two to 15 years in prison. But public pressure—"Free Huey" became a popular slogan of the day—helped Newton's cause. The case was eventually dismissed after two retrials ended with hung juries.}}</ref><ref name="Newton2009">{{cite book|author=Huey P. Newton|title=Revolutionary Suicide: (Penguin Classics Deluxe Edition)|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WvZPJyeUTUUC|date=September 29, 2009|publisher=Penguin Group US|isbn=978-1-101-14047-5}}</ref> * November: The activity at the Diggers' Free Store is the impetus for an anti-hippie turf war with local thugs in New York City.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Wetzteon|first1=Ross|last2=Ortega|first2=Tony|title=Not Everyone Loves You For Giving Things Away|url=http://blogs.villagevoice.com/runninscared/2010/03/hippies_free_st.php|website=villagevoice.com|publisher=The Village Voice|accessdate=August 15, 2014|date=November 16, 1967|quote=Hippies' Free Store Not So Popular With Thugs (headline from Ortega's excerpt of original article, published by Village Voice 2010-03-24)|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140819125806/http://blogs.villagevoice.com/runninscared/2010/03/hippies_free_st.php|archivedate=August 19, 2014|df=}}</ref> * November 9: ''[[Rolling Stone|Rolling Stone Magazine]]'': John Lennon is featured on the cover of the first issue in a photo from the film ''[[How I Won The War]]''. ''Rolling Stone'' grows to become a focal point for news and reviews during the era, and beyond.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Fagan|first1=Alexandra|title=Rolling Stone's First Issue|url=http://rockhall.com/blog/post/10252_rolling-stone-first-issue-cover-story/|website=rockhall.com|accessdate=2016-01-14}}</ref> * November 10: ''[[Disraeli Gears]]'': [[Cream (band)|Cream's]] quintessential psychedelic rock album is released.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Barker|first1=Andrew|title=Cream Bassist Jack Bruce Dies at 71|url=https://variety.com/2014/music/obituaries-people-news/jack-bruce-cream-bassist-dies-at-71-1201339169/|accessdate=2016-01-14|publisher=Variety|date=2014-10-24}}</ref> * November 10: The [[Moody Blues]]' masterpiece ''[[Days of Future Passed]]'', featuring psychedelic themes and the [[London Festival Orchestra]], is released.<ref name="Perone2012">{{cite book|author=James E. Perone|title=The Album: A Guide to Pop Music's Most Provocative, Influential, and Important Creations|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gzl1lBFXKhQC&pg=RA2-PT79|date=17 October 2012|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-0-313-37907-9|pages=2–}}</ref> * November 20: Police using tear gas charge a large student demonstration against corporate recruiters for [[napalm]] manufacturer Dow Chemical at [[San Jose State College]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Students Demonstrate Against Dow Chemical Company|url=http://www.history.com/this-day-in-history/students-demonstrate-against-dow-chemical-company|website=history.com|publisher=A&E Television Networks|accessdate=2016-10-05}}</ref> * November 24: [[I Am the Walrus]]: The Beatles release John Lennon's psychedelic [[Coda (music)|coda]]. The album ''[[Magical Mystery Tour]]'' arrives November 27.<ref name="DeRogatis2003b">{{cite book|author=Jim DeRogatis|title=Turn on Your Mind: Four Decades of Great Psychedelic Rock|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=U7cQmRsLgN8C&pg=PA50|date=1 January 2003|publisher=Hal Leonard Corporation|isbn=978-0-634-05548-5|pages=50–}}</ref> * December 4–8: Anti-war groups across the US attempt to shut down draft board centers, Dr. Benjamin Spock and poet Allen Ginsberg are among the 585 arrested. * December 10: Monterey Pop Fest standout and soon-to-be soul legend [[Otis Redding]] dies in a plane crash at age 26.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Wenner|first1=Jann|title=Otis Redding: The Crown Prince of Soul Is Dead – The singer dies in a plane crash at 26 years old|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/otis-redding-the-crown-prince-of-soul-is-dead-19680120|accessdate=2016-05-09|publisher=Rolling Stone|date=1968-01-20|quote=Otis Redding, 26 years old, a former well-driller from Macon, Georgia, died in a plane crash in an icy Wisconsin lake on December 10. With him were the five teen-age members of the Bar-Kays, a group which made the popular instrumental, "Soul Finger," and who backed Otis on his recent tours and appearances. Otis was headed from Cleveland, Ohio, to a Sunday evening concert in Madison, Wisconsin. It was his first tour in the private plane he had just purchased. His plane hit the surface of the fog-shrouded Madison lake with tremendous force, widely scattering the debris. He was only four miles from the Madison Municipal Airport. On Tuesday, teams of divers were still dredging the bottom of the lake in a search for the bodies.}}</ref> * December 22: Owsley Stanley is found in possession of 350,000 doses of LSD and 1,500 doses of STP, arrested, and sentenced to 3 years. * December 31: [[Youth International Party|Yippies]]: "Yippie" is coined by radicals Jerry Rubin, Abbie Hoffman, [[Anita Hoffman]], [[Dick Gregory]], [[Nancy Kurshan]] and [[Paul Krassner]]. In January, the Youth International Party is formed. Inspired by the Diggers, the humorous Yippies also take the counterculture protest movement into the realm of performance theater.<ref name="GreenbergWatts2008">{{cite book|author1=Brian Greenberg|author2=Linda S. Watts|author3=Richard A. Greenwald|title=Social History of the United States [10 volumes]|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xypn4djxVD4C&pg=RA6-PA207|date=23 October 2008|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-1-59884-128-2|pages=6–}}</ref> * December: US troops in Vietnam total 486,000. US war dead total 15,000. * Originally marketed (but withdrawn) by [[Parke-Davis]] as a surgical anesthetic, [[Phencyclidine|PCP (Angel Dust)]] begins to appear as a "recreational" drug. The limited street demand for the deadly dissociative compound, which induces horrific hallucinations, violent psychoses, and self-mutilation peaks in the late 1970s.<ref name="Inciardi1990">{{cite book|author=James A. Inciardi|title=Handbook of Drug Control in the United States|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Je3IC_PZHkgC&pg=PA16|year=1990|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|isbn=978-0-313-26190-9|pages=16–}}</ref><ref name="Buxton2011">{{cite book|author=Julia Buxton|title=The Politics of Narcotic Drugs: A Survey|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sYJaBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA271|date=6 April 2011|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-136-88061-2|pages=271–}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=PCP Fast Facts|url=https://www.justice.gov/archive/ndic/pubs4/4440/#risks|website=www.justice.gov|publisher=National Drug Intelligence Center, a component of the U.S. Department of Justice.|accessdate=2018-05-29|quote=PCP is an addictive drug; its use often results in psychological dependence, craving, and compulsive behavior. PCP produces unpleasant psychological effects, and users often become violent or suicidal.}}</ref> * Chemist Alexander Shulgin, who first synthesized the psychedelic compound DOM (STP) in 1963, first ingests the MDMA (Ecstasy) he'd earlier synthesized in his former Dow Chemical lab. Soon, mind-altering properties unknown since patent of the compound by Merck in 1912 are reported.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Karch|first1=Stephen|title=The Open Forensic Science Journal, 2011, 4, 20–24 20 1874-4028/11 2011 Bentham Open Open Access A Historical Review of MDMA|journal=The Open Forensic Science Journal|date=2011|volume=4|pages=20–24|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/228474600_A_historical_review_of_MDMA|accessdate=2016-08-13|quote=University and industry based medicinal chemists took up where the Army had left off and scientific human experimentation finally began in earnest. Psychiatrists suspected that MDMA had useful therapeutic properties. Much of the enthusiasm for this line of research was a result of active proselytizing by a former Dow Chemical employee Alexander Shulgin who first synthesized MDMA as an academic exercise in 1965. He did not try the drug himself until 1967. Marie Kleinman, a graduate student in the medicinal chemistry group that Shulgin advised at San Francisco State University, finally convinced Shulgin to try the drug. In 1976, Shulgin shared his enthusiasm about MDMA with Leo Zeff, a psychologist from Oakland, California. Zeff, who had actually been using the drug since 1961, began giving MDMA to his patients, using small doses as an aid to therapeutic interaction. Zeff proselytized actively and introduced MDMA to hundreds of psychologists around the nation, including Ann Shulgin, whom Alexander Shulgin met in 1979, and married in 1981 [6].}}</ref>
===1968=== * [[Tom Wolfe|Tom Wolfe's]] ''[[The Electric Kool Aid Acid Test|The Electric Kool-Aid Acid Test]]'' is published.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Gross|first1=Terry|title=Tom Wolfe: Chronicling Counterculture's 'Acid Test'|url=https://www.npr.org/2011/08/12/139383916/tom-wolfe-chronicling-countercultures-acid-test|website=npr.org|publisher=National Public Radio (US)|accessdate=July 9, 2014|date=October 29, 1987|quote=Fresh Air: Text & Audio of Interview w/Wolfe}}</ref> * January: Owsley-inspired pioneer [[Heavy metal music|Heavy Metal]] band [[Blue Cheer]] release ''[[Vincebus Eruptum]]'', as early metal ground-breakers [[Iron Butterfly]] release their debut [[Heavy (Iron Butterfly album)|''Heavy'']].<ref>{{cite web|title=Blue Cheer Biography|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/artists/blue-cheer/biography|website=rollingstone.com|publisher=Rolling Stone Magazine|accessdate=July 9, 2014|date=2001|quote=Blue Cheer appeared in spring 1968 with a thunderously loud remake of Eddie Cochran's "Summertime Blues" that many regard as the first true heavy-metal record. One of the first hard-rock power trios, the group was named for an especially high-quality strain of LSD. Its manager, Gut, was an ex-Hell's Angel. (This biography originally appeared in ''The Rolling Stone Encyclopedia of Rock & Roll'' (Simon & Schuster, 2001))}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=The 100 Greatest Metal Albums of All Time|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/the-100-greatest-metal-albums-of-all-time-w486923|website=Rollng Stone|accessdate=2017-10-08|quote=With a crash of thunder, the ringing of ominous church bells and one of the loudest guitar sounds in history, a heavy new music genre was born in earnest on a Friday the 13th early in 1970. Its roots stretch back to the late Sixties, when artists like Blue Cheer, Iron Butterfly and Led Zeppelin cranked their amps to play bluesy, shit-kicking rockers, but it wasn't until that fateful day, when Black Sabbath issued the first, front-to-back, wholly heavy-metal album – their gloomy self-titled debut – that a band had mastered the sound of the genre, one that still resonates nearly 50 years later: heavy metal.}}</ref> * January 22: [[Laugh-In]]: The sketch comedy "phenomenon that both reflected and mocked the era's counterculture", and brought it into "mainstream living rooms", debuts on US TV.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://sanfrancisco.cbslocal.com/2011/12/04/laugh-in-comic-alan-sues-dies-at-85/ |title='Laugh-In' Comic Alan Sues Dies At 85 |date=December 4, 2011 |website=sanfrancisco.cbslocal.com |publisher=CBS/AP |accessdate=June 17, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/people/2008-05-25-martin-obit_N.htm |title='Laugh-in' comic Dick Martin dies at 86 |last1=Cheng |first1=Jim |date=May 26, 2008 |website=usatoday.com |publisher=USA Today/Gannett |accessdate=June 17, 2014}}</ref> * January 31: The [[Tet Offensive]] is launched by the NVA and Vietcong. Western forces are victorious on the battlefield, but not in the press.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Oberdorfer|first1=Don|title=TET: Who Won?; A North Vietnamese battlefield defeat that led to victory, the Tet Offensive still triggers debate nearly four decades later|url=http://www.smithsonianmag.com/history/tet-who-won-99179501/|website=smithsonianmag.com|publisher=Smithsonian Magazine|accessdate=January 13, 2015|date=November 2004}}</ref><ref name="Arnold2012">{{cite book|author=James Arnold|title=Tet Offensive 1968: Turning point in Vietnam|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZD3tB5lRYVUC&pg=PA88|date=September 20, 2012|publisher=Osprey Publishing|isbn=978-1-78200-428-8|pages=88–}}</ref> * February 1: Following the free-form programming experimentations at [[KFRC-FM#History|KFRC-FM]] in San Francisco, [[WYCD|WABX-FM]] in Detroit and other stations nationwide begin to officially change format. FM playlists and other content are now chosen by local DJs, not corporate executives or record companies. The [[Progressive rock (radio format)|Progressive Rock]] format takes hold.<ref name="Inc.1968">{{cite book|author=Nielsen Business Media, Inc.|title=Billboard|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pQgEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA35|date=March 30, 1968|publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc.|pages=35–|issn=0006-2510}}</ref> * February 4: Beat figure and Merry Prankster [[Neal Cassady]] dies in Mexico of unknown causes at age 41.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Staton|first1=Scott|title=Neal Cassady: American Muse, Holy Fool|url=http://www.newyorker.com/books/page-turner/neal-cassady-american-muse-holy-fool|website=newyorker.com|publisher=The New Yorker Magazine|accessdate=November 13, 2015|date=December 12, 2012}}</ref> * February 8: [[Orangeburg Massacre]]: Police fire on and kill three protesting segregation at a South Carolina bowling alley.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Bass|first1=Jack|title=Documenting the Orangeburg Massacre|url=http://www.nieman.harvard.edu/reports/article/100992/Documenting-the-Orangeburg-Massacre.aspx|website=www.nieman.harvard.edu|publisher=Nieman Foundation for Journalism at Harvard / Harvard University|accessdate=July 9, 2014|date=2003|quote=Campus killings of black students received little news coverage in 1968, but a book about them keeps their memory alive.}}</ref> * February 15: [[The Beatles in India]]: All four Beatles, along with fellow devotees such as Mike Love, Donovan and [[Mia Farrow]], journey to [[Rishikesh]] in India to study [[Transcendental Meditation technique|Transcendental Meditation]] under [[Maharishi Mahesh Yogi]]. [[John Lennon]] and [[George Harrison]] are the last of the celebrities to leave; they depart amid unsubstantiated rumors of the Maharishi's sexual impropriety toward some of the female students<ref>{{cite book|last=Goldberg|first=Philip|authorlink= |title=American Veda: From Emerson and the Beatles to Yoga and Meditation – How Indian Spirituality Changed the West|publisher=[[Harmony Books]]|location=New York, NY|year=2010|isbn=978-0-385-52134-5|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=b3Mdr3IMgW0C&vq=Beatles&dq |p=161}}</ref> and the band members' suspicions that he was using their fame for self-promotion.<ref>{{cite book|first=Mark|last=Paytress|chapter=A Passage to India|year=2003|title=[[Mojo (magazine)#Special editions|Mojo Special Limited Edition]]: 1000 Days of Revolution (The Beatles' Final Years – Jan 1, 1968 to Sept 27, 1970)|location=London|publisher=[[Emap]]|pp=15–17}}</ref> * February 27: 1950s teen vocal star [[Frankie Lymon]] dies of a heroin overdose in New York City at age 25.<ref name="Company1998">{{cite book|author=Johnson Publishing Company|title=Ebony|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jXsbJEgguzIC&pg=PA68|date=December 1998|publisher=Johnson Publishing Company|pages=68–|issn=0012-9011}}</ref> * February 29: Kerner Report: The ''[[Kerner Report|Report of the National Advisory Commission on Civil Disorders]]'' is released after seven months of investigation into US urban rioting, and states that "our nation is moving towards two societies, one black, one white – separate and unequal."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Moyers|first1=Bill|title=The Kerner Commission – 40 Years Later|url=https://www.pbs.org/moyers/journal/03282008/profile.html|website=pbs.org|publisher=Bill Moyers Journal / Public Affairs Television|accessdate=July 10, 2014|date=March 28, 2008|quote=... the Kerner Report, with its stark conclusion that "Our nation is moving towards two societies — one white, one black — separate and unequal" — was a best-seller. It was also the source of great controversy and remains so today.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Thernstrom|first1=Stephan|last2=Siegel|first2=Fred|last3=Woodson|first3=Robert|title=The Kerner Commission Report|url=http://www.heritage.org/research/lecture/the-kerner-commission-report|website=heritage.org|publisher=Heritage Foundation|accessdate=July 10, 2014|date=June 24, 1998|quote=This lecture was held at The Heritage Foundation on March 13, 1998.}}</ref> * March 16: [[My Lai Massacre]] in Vietnam. Apparent wanton rape and murder of innocents by US GIs creates enormous new anti-war outcry when news leaks in 1969.<ref>{{cite news|title=3 Honored for Saving Lives at My Lai|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/07/us/3-honored-for-saving-lives-at-my-lai.html|website=nytimes.com|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=July 10, 2014|date=March 7, 1998|quote=Thirty years after one of the darkest moments in United States military history, three soldiers who happened upon the My Lai massacre and risked their lives to save Vietnamese civilians by aiming their weapons at fellow Americans were proclaimed heroes today by the Army.}}</ref><ref name="Allison2012">{{cite book|author=William Thomas Allison|title=My Lai: An American Atrocity in the Vietnam War|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=std2t1r25s8C&pg=PP10|date=July 21, 2012|publisher=JHU Press|isbn=978-1-4214-0706-7|pages=10–}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Report of the Department of the Army Review of the Preliminary Investigations into the My Lai Incident: Vol. 1, the Report of the Investigation|url=https://www.loc.gov/rr/frd/Military_Law/pdf/RDAR-Vol-I.pdf|website=loc.gov|publisher=United States Army|accessdate=July 10, 2014|date=March 14, 1970}}</ref> * March 17: London police stop 10,000 anti-war marchers from violently storming the US Embassy. 200 are arrested. The protest serves as partial inspiration for the Rolling Stones' most notable political foray, "[[Street Fighting Man]]".<ref>{{cite news|title=1968: Anti-Vietnam demo turns violent|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/march/17/newsid_2818000/2818967.stm|website=bbc.co.uk|publisher=BBC (UK)|accessdate=July 10, 2014|date=2008|quote=The trouble followed a big rally in Trafalgar square, when an estimated 10,000 demonstrated against American action in Vietnam and British support for the United States.}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Hoyland|first1=John|title=Power to the people: The year was 1968 and, worldwide, there was revolution in the air. But when John Hoyland attacked John Lennon's politics in a radical paper, he didn't expect the fiery Beatle to rise to the bait|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2008/mar/15/popandrock.pressandpublishing|accessdate=2016-04-14|publisher=Guardian News and Media Limited|date=2008-03-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Burley|first1=Leo|title=Jagger vs Lennon: London's riots of 1968 provided the backdrop to a rock'n'roll battle royale|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/features/jagger-vs-lennon-londons-riots-of-1968-provided-the-backdrop-to-a-rocknroll-battle-royale-792450.html|website=independent.co.uk|publisher=The Independent (UK)|accessdate=July 11, 2014|date=March 9, 2008|quote=Forty years ago, the world was on the brink of revolution. Kennedy|RFK In]]: NY Senator Robert F. Kennedy, a long-time supporter of US policy in Vietnam, speaks out against the war for the first time, and announces his candidacy for President.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Kennedy|first1=Robert Francis|title=Robert F. The 4.9-million-barrel Deepwater Horizon disaster, the worst offshore oil spill in U.S. history, stirred new and broad opposition to offshore development.}}</ref> * January 29: [[Sir George Williams Computer Riot]]: the largest student campus occupation in Canadian history results in millions in damage in Montreal.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Lindeman|first1=Tracey|title=A look back at Montreal's race-related 1969 Computer Riot|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/a-look-back-at-montreal-s-race-related-1969-computer-riot-1.2538765|website=cbc.ca|publisher=Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|accessdate=December 31, 2014|date=February 15, 2014|quote=Forty-five years ago this week, violent protests and a 14-day sit-in over racism at Sir George Williams University exploded, causing $2 million in damage for the school.}}</ref> * January 30: [[Let it Be (album)|''Let it Be'']]: The Beatles plus Billy Preston perform in public as a group for the [[The Beatles' rooftop concert|last time]] on the roof atop their offices in London. Humans walk on the moon. A tablet with the inscription "We Came in Peace for All Mankind" is left on the lunar surface.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Wilford|first1=John Noble|title=We Reach the Moon|date=1969|publisher=New York Times / Bantam|location=New York|isbn=9780552082051|page=XV|quote=The Story of Man's Greatest Adventure}}</ref> * July 21: Andy Warhol's ''[[Blue Movie]]'' premieres at the [[New Andy Warhol Garrick Theatre]]. The events shock the nation. For many, the crimes and Manson's "family" are seen as products of the counterculture.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.biography.com/people/charles-manson-9397912#awesm=~oGk3xdXSOXv88x |title=Charles Manson Biography: Charles Manson is an American cult leader whose followers carried out several notorious murders in the late 1960s and inspired the book Helter Skelter.|date=2014 |website=biography.com |publisher=A&E Television Networks, LLC |accessdate=June 5, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://newrepublic.com/article/114233/stacks-charles-manson-helter-skelter-and-counterculture |title=From the Stacks (January 4, 1975): "Demon in the Counterculture" |last1=Woods |first1=William Crawford |date=August 8, 2013 |website=newrepublic.com |publisher=The New Republic |accessdate=June 5, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/08/02/weekinreview/02decurtis.html?_r=0|title=Peace, Love and Charlie Manson: The Anti-Woodstock? |last1=DeCurtis |first1=Anthony |date=August 1, 2009 |website=nytimes.com |publisher=The New York Times Co. |accessdate=June 5, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Sheffield|first1=Rob|title=Heart of Darkness: A Charles Manson Timeline The helter-skelter life of America's most infamous criminal|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/culture/news/heart-of-darkness-a-charles-manson-timeline-20131121|website=rollingstone.com|publisher=Rolling Stone|accessdate=2016-05-01|date=2013-11-21}}</ref> * August 15–18: [[Woodstock festival|Woodstock]]: An estimated 300,000–500,000 people gather in upstate New York for "3 Days of Peace & Music" at the watershed event in counterculture history.<ref name="Gair2007">{{cite book|author=Christopher Gair|title=The American Counterculture|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1cVwRtI9o08C&pg=PA205|year=2007|publisher=Edinburgh University Press|isbn=978-0-7486-1989-4|pages=205–}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Volunteers|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OzHBr0ndKus|accessdate=December 30, 2014|date=1969}}</ref> * August 19: Immediately following Woodstock, David Crosby, Stephen Stills, [[Joni Mitchell]] and Jefferson Airplane appear on the [[Dick Cavett Show]]. The Airplane's lyric "''Up against the wall, motherfuckers!''" in the performance of "[[We Can Be Together]]" slips past the censors and airs on national television.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Dick Cavett Show|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=abPpq6hQ67I|accessdate=December 30, 2014|date=August 19, 1969}}</ref> * August 30–31: Second [[Isle of Wight Festival]] attracts 150,000 people to see acts including Bob Dylan and [[The Band]], [[The Who]], [[Free (band)|Free]], [[Joe Cocker]] and the Moody Blues. * September: ''[[Penthouse Magazine|Penthouse]]'': The first US issue of [[Robert Guccione|Robert Guccione's]] explicit monthly hits newsstands, and is later called "the adult magazine that wormed its way into the kinkier recesses of the libidinal subconscious and, arguably, did more to liberate puritan America from its deepest sexual taboos than any magazine before or since."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Colapinto|first1=John|title=The Twilight of Bob Guccione|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/culture/news/the-twilight-of-bob-guccione-20101021|website=rollingstone.com|publisher=Rolling Stone|accessdate=2015-11-27|date=2010-10-21}}</ref> * September 1–2: Race rioting in Hartford, CT and Camden, NJ. * September 2: [[Ho Chi Minh]], President of communist North Vietnam, aggressor and prime mover of the Vietnam War, dies. Ho's war rages on after his death.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/history/historic_figures/ho_chi_minh.shtml |title=Ho Chi Minh (1890–1969) |website=www.bbc.co.uk |publisher=BBC |accessdate=May 4, 2014}}</ref> * September 6: ''[[H.R. The Chronicle's front page from June 12, 1971, covers the federal removal of the last of the American Indians who had seized Alcatraz Island in 1969.}}</ref> * December: Total US casualties (dead and seriously wounded) in Vietnam total 100,000. * December 1: The first draft lottery in the US since World War II is held in New York City and broadcast live on CBS. Later statistical analysis indicates the lottery method (birthdates in capsules pulled from a hand-rotated drum) is flawed, leaving certain birthdates more likely to be drawn than others.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Starr|first1=Norton|title=Nonrandom Risk: The 1970 Draft Lottery|journal=Journal of Statistics Education|date=1997|volume=v.5, n.2|quote=Abstract: The 1970 draft lottery for birthdates is reviewed as an example of a government effort at randomization whose inadequacy can be exhibited by a wide variety of statistical approaches. State and federal narcs rounded up 19 people in the Dead raid, and were none too polite about it, either."}}</ref> * February: Weather Underground bombings and arsons in US states of NY, CA, WA, MD, & MI. * February 18: [[Chicago 7]] verdicts are handed down: two are exonerated, five are soon sentenced for "crossing state lines with intent to incite a riot", but all the convictions and sentences are later reversed. * February 23–26: Students riot at University of California-Santa Barbara. * February 25–28: Students riot, occupy campus buildings, etc. at [[SUNY Buffalo]], NY. * March 6: [[Greenwich Village townhouse explosion]]: Three members of the Weather Underground are killed while assembling a bomb in New York City.<ref name="Wilkerson2011">{{cite book|author=Cathy Wilkerson|title=Flying Close to the Sun: My Life and Times as a Weatherman|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aPGfSQZKCQ4C|date=4 January 2011|publisher=Seven Stories Press|isbn=978-1-60980-070-3}}</ref> * March 26: The documentary film ''[[Woodstock (film)|Woodstock]]'' is released. * Late March: [[Fleetwood Mac]] founder [[Peter Green (musician)|Peter Green]] and bandmate [[Danny Kirwan]] get waylaid at a bizarre party at the Highfisch-Kommune cult/commune, Munich. Rumours of his demise began to spread, and sightings of him became notorious. After years battling his mental illness, Green is writing and recording again. Booker|title=Historical Dictionary of American Cinema|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Y04MQEgHbZsC&pg=PR25|date=March 17, 2011|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=978-0-8108-7459-6|pages=25–}}</ref> * April 10: Paul McCartney, when promoting [[McCartney (album)|his first solo album]], announces that the Beatles have disbanded. * April 15: 100,000 gather on Boston Common to protest the Vietnam War; about 500 radicals attempt to seize microphone, disrupting meeting. * April 22: [[Earth Day]]: The first event recognizing the precarious environmental state of planet earth is held.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Berman|first1=Eliza|title=Meet the Organizers of the Very First Earth Day|url=http://time.com/3772160/earth-day/|accessdate=2016-03-26|publisher=Time, Inc.|date=2015-04-22|quote=How a troupe of twenty-somethings mobilized millions of Americans to speak out on the environment}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Gibbens|first1=Sarah|title=How the Environment Has Changed Since the First Earth Day|url=https://relay.nationalgeographic.com/proxy/distribution/public/amp/2018/04/earth-day-then-now-history-science-spd|website=natonalgeographic.com|publisher=National Geographic Society|accessdate=2018-04-28|date=2018-04-21|quote=When Earth Day was first created in 1970, it rode the coattails of a decade filled with social activism. Voting rights were strengthened, civil rights were outlined, and women were demanding equal treatment. But there was no Environmental Protection Agency, no Clean Air Act, or Clean Water Act. Officially, the United Nations recognizes this upcoming April 22 as International Mother Earth Day. Across the globe, millions of people take part in Earth Day. According to the Earth Day Network, one of the largest activist bodies organizing Earth Day events, people celebrate by holding marches, planting trees, meeting with local representatives, and cleaning up their local environments.}}</ref> * April 30: President Nixon reveals secret US military operations in [[Cambodian Campaign|Cambodia]]. * May 1–3: 13,000 people take part in peaceful demonstrations at [[Yale University]] in support of defendants in the [[New Haven Black Panther trials]]. * May 2: Radicals among the students at [[Kent State University]] protesting the spread of the war into Cambodia burn the [[ROTC]] building to the ground. Ohio Governor [[Jim Rhodes]] calls in the National Guard at the request of Kent's Mayor.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.kentwired.com/may_4/article_ff368f1b-5b9f-5642-bb16-1199c5830fee.html |title=May 4 Sequence of Events |date=May 4, 2010 |website=kentwired.com |publisher=kentwired |accessdate=April 30, 2014}}</ref> * May 4: In what is perhaps the greatest tragedy of the stateside anti-war protest movement, poorly trained soldiers of the Ohio National Guard are set loose into confrontation with – and open fire on – unarmed students at [[Kent State shootings|Kent State University]] leaving [[Ohio (Crosby, Stills, Nash & Young song)|four dead]] and nine wounded, including Dean Kahler, who was paralyzed.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wksu.org/news/story/35452 |title=Dean Kahler: visitors' Center helps him move past May 4, 1970 |last1=Bhatia |first1=Kabir |date=May 3, 2013 |website=wksu.org |publisher=WKSU Public Radio |accessdate=June 10, 2014}}</ref> * May 4: Holding Together: A benefit for Timothy Leary is held at the Village Gate in NYC. Jimi Hendrix and [[Johnny Winter]] perform.<ref name="Bingham2016">{{cite book|author=Clara Bingham|title=Witness to the Revolution: Radicals, Resisters, Vets, Hippies, and the Year America Lost Its Mind and Found Its Soul|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-CIYDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA449|date=May 2016|publisher=Random House Publishing Group|isbn=978-0-8129-9318-9|pages=449–}}</ref><ref name="SullivanWinter2010">{{cite book|author1=Mary Lou Sullivan|author2=Johnny Winter|title=Raisin' Cain: The Wild and Raucous Story of Johnny Winter|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LAbvjOeFw8kC&pg=PA132|year=2010|publisher=Backbeat Books|isbn=978-0-87930-973-2|pages=132–}}</ref> * May 5: The [[Nonproliferation Treaty|International Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty]] takes effect. * May 6: [[Student Strike of 1970]]: Many colleges across the US shut down in protest of the war and the Kent State events. * May 8: [[Hard Hat Riot]]: Construction workers confront anti-war demonstrators, Wall St., New York City. They march again May 11. On May 20, 100,000 construction workers and longshoremen demonstrate in favor of administration war policy at New York City Hall.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Walker |first1=Jesse |title=Hardhats for Peace, College Kids for War: The surprising shape of public opinion in the Vietnam era.|url=https://reason.com/archives/2013/07/09/hardhats-for-peace-college-kids-for-war |website=reason.org |publisher=Reason Foundation |accessdate=2018-06-10 |date=2013-09-13 |quote=Book Review: Hardhats, Hippies, and Hawks: The Vietnam Antiwar Movement as Myth and Memory. The Hard Hat Riot of May 1970 has managed somehow to be both widely forgotten and universally remembered. The incident itself, in which rampaging New York construction workers beat up hippies and demanded that City Hall raise the American flag, is a piece of historical trivia; most Americans born after it have little inkling that it occurred, and even the people who were around at the time are likely to be hazy on the details. But the image of a pro-war worker in a hardhat punching a privileged protester is enshrined in our cultural memory. It's what the late '60s and early '70s were supposed to look like: college kids who hated the Vietnam War and blue-collar patriots who loved the flag.}}</ref> * May 8: Attempting to "rescue" his child from what he believes to be a hippie commune, father Arville Garland murders his daughter Sandra and three others as they sleep in Detroit. The events are eerily similar to those depicted in the hippie-bashing film [[Joe (1970 film)|''Joe'']], which was filmed prior to – but released after – the murders.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Carr|first1=Tom|title=Blood on the Mitten|date=2016|publisher=Chandler Lake Books / Mission Point Press|isbn=9781943338078|pages=47|edition=1st}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Pevere|first1=Geoff|title=How Joe and Patton could, 40 years on, play again today|url=https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/2010/06/18/how_joe_and_patton_could_40_years_on_play_again_today.html|accessdate=2017-06-17|publisher=The Toronto Star|date=2010-06-18|quote=Joe, like Patton, had its true-life historical hook. Two months before the movie opened, and on the very same day as the Hard Hat Riot in Manhattan, a middle-aged railroad worker named Arville Douglas Garland entered a Detroit university residence (known, apparently, as a hippie haven) and shot and killed four students — including his daughter and her boyfriend. Although equipped for the rampage with multiple weapons and extra ammo, Garland was ultimately handed a light sentence by the same judge who'd seen Joe as part of his deliberation process and rejected any prospective jurors who'd done the same. Garland was seen to be let off lightly, but justly so by the hundreds of supporters who sent the killer letters endorsing his actions. At the time, it was reported that no one wrote to suggest that Garland had given the murdered kids anything but what they deserved.}}</ref> * May 9: 100,000 rally against war in Washington, DC. At 4:15am, President Nixon defies Secret Service security, and leaves the White House to meet and chat with surprised protesters camping out at the [[Lincoln Memorial]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Jennings|first1=Peter|last2=Jarriel|first2=Tom|title=5/9/1970: Nationwide Student Strike|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Archives/video/student-strike-1970-vietnam-cambodia-kent-state-10075782|website=abcnews.go.com|publisher=ABC News Internet Ventures|accessdate=September 26, 2014|date=May 9, 1970|quote=Students gather to protest the invasion of Cambodia and the Kent State massacre. Ellis later quits drugs, becomes a recovery counselor, and expresses regret over drug abuse during his playing career.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Getlen|first1=Larry|title=How Dock Ellis Dropped Acid and Threw a Ho-Hitter|url=https://nypost.com/2014/08/31/pitcher-dock-ellis-dropped-acid-then-threw-a-no-hitter/|website=nypost.com|publisher=The New York Post|accessdate=September 4, 2014|date=August 31, 2014|quote=Later in life, Ellis, who ultimately got straight and became a drug counselor, expressed shame about what he had done. ===1973=== * January 1: Bangladeshis burn down the US Information Service in Dacca in protest of the bombing of North Vietnam. * January 2: Aerial bombing of North Vietnam resumes after a 36-hour New Year's truce. * January 4: Forty neutral member nations of the UN formally protest the US bombing campaign. * January 5: Canada's Parliament votes unanimously to condemn US bombing actions and calls for them to cease. * January 10: Anti-war demonstrators attack US consulate in Lyons, France, and burn down the library of America House in Frankfurt, West Germany. * January 15: Anti-war protesters occupy US consulate in Amsterdam. * January 15: President Nixon suspends the bombing, citing progress in the Peace talks with Hanoi. West German Chancellor [[Willy Brandt]] warns Nixon that US relations with Western Europe are at risk.<ref>Edward W. Knappman, ed. ''South Vietnam: Volume 7, US-Communist Confrontation in Southeast Asia 1972–1973.'' p. 226.</ref> * January 22: Former US President Lyndon B.
